results.description:
This group is about becoming more active, trying new things, learning to eat better and live healthier.  Let's face it, in our busy lives, it's difficult to stay on track and motivated!

That's why I've signed up to take the 21 day transformation challenge offered in Prevention Magazine's May 2016 issue.  

I'd love anyone interested to join the challenge with me and together we can support one another in becoming healthier!

 Please  log on to learn more about the challenge and sign up at:

prevention.com/21daychallenge

The challenge begins May 1st.  It's 19.95, but there's a coupon code in the magazine article which will enable you to pay only 14.96.  You may also use the coupon code "MINDANDBODY" when you checkout that I received from my receipt, if you don't buy the issue.

This is all about learning to eat clean, delicious, "real" food as well as moving our bodies more!

I'll schedule a walk each weekend, which can help us meet some of the fitness goals of the challenge. The program adjusts for each fitness level so everyone can do what is comfortable for them.

We can share during our walks how we're all doing, any struggles or suggestions to help others. I'll also start a discussion board here on meet up for additional support. Remember, too, that the Prevention challenge also has a discussion/support board.

Even if you don't join the challenge, please join the walks!
results.name: Let's take Prevention Magazine's 21 Day Transformation Challenge together!

results.description:
Let’s get “All the brilliant people, working on the same thing, at the same time, in the same space, and at the same computer.“  This is “immersion training meets powerful questions”. Learn by doing, and then have just the right amount of reflection and talk to fuel another round of immersion learning.

Mob Programming is a fairly new concept. This conference offers you a good grasp of it with a mix of talks, trying it out, and discussing with your peers.

Join us for two days of workshops and peer learning with talks from the founders of Mob Programming. 

This event is not filled to capacity.  We are doing registration and payment on a link outside of Meetup, so please do not try to RSVP here.  For detailed information or to register, please go to the Mob Programming Conference website: mobprogrammingconference.com

The Mob Programming Conference is an event of Agile New England, a chapter of the ACM.

results.description:
Greetings Photographers!  Time to put our photography skills to good use. You have been learning how to take better pictures as a member of this group for some time. Now we have an exciting opportunity to put our skills to use during this fantastic event. I will be there and hope you will too!  Suzanne

We have been invited to serve as photographers for the Walk for Hunger this Sunday in partnership with The Curious Soul Photo School. Pro-bono photography positions are available throughout the Walk route along the scenic 10-mile route along the Charles River through Boston & Cambridge. Here is a map of the route. They are also looking for early morning photographers to be positioned at the start of the Walk on the Boston Common.


On Sunday, May 1st 2016, more than 40,000 people will come together on the Boston Common to make a powerful statement about hunger in Massachusetts. Money raised from the Walk will be used to develop and fund hundreds of critical programs that provide hunger relief to families and individuals across the state. Visit the website here to learn more. http://www.projectbread.org/walk-for-hunger/


Here is how it will work.

How do I get involved?  Two easy steps. First you RSVP here then  <a>You contact [masked]</a>  directly. Kelly will let you know what time slots and locations still need photographers. Then you REPORT TO THE MEDIA TENT on the Boston Common to pick up your T Shirt, Volunteer Pass and information packet. This includes guidelines for what sort of images they are looking for.

How much time is involved? We are asking you to take pictures for 2 or 3 hours.

What do I need to do?  Bring your camera and show up at your designated time and place to take photos during the walk. Bring a friend with you. You will be collecting the names and contact information of the walkers so the photos can be used on line and in future articles. They will be happy to give permission. 

Are there any special forms? Yes, a permission form will be provided for you to print and bring along. This is what you will have the walkers sign. If you can't print them in advance, you can pick them up at the media tent in the staging area. 

Do I get photo credit? If one of your photos is used in an article photo credit will be given to you. More about this later once you RSVP. 

What kind of photos should I take? Kelly is looking for shots of small groups of walkers and individuals. You know how to capture the joy and excitement of an event so this is a great way to practice your skills. I will provide some suggested camera settings and composition tips for taking great event photos. 

What do I do with the photos? After the event you have two choices of how to get the photos to Kelly. You can download them at the Walk for Hunger Media Tent on the common that day, OR you can do some edits, select your best photos, and send the files via Drop Box a day or two after the event. Drop box is free and easy to set up. WE can help you if you have questions about how to do this.

You can also post 5 of your favorite photos from the event here on our site as usual to receive constructive critique from the other photographers that participate in the event. This is a great way to build you skills and do something good for others at the same time. 

Looking forward to seeing you RSVP YES!  And don't forget to contact Kelly today.

<a>[masked]</a> for you assignment.


Thank you for participating. Suzanne Take Better Pictures Organizer and Founder of  The Curious Soul Photo School.
results.how_to_find_us: Details provided once you RSVP to Kelly

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to three of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Tom, Field, and Willey. We will use Avalon Trail, A-Z Trail, and Mt. Tom Spur to reach our first summit. From there we will use Willey Ridge Trail to reach Field and Willey before turning around and using Willey Ridge Trail and Avalon Trail to get back to the trailhead.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 10.1 miles and climb about 3,700 feet. It should take an average hiker about 7 hours to complete (this doesn't include time taking breaks). This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/23-Mt-Field-4340--29-Mt-Willey-4285--39-Mt-Tom-4051

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.196046939000496&lon=-71.43322872899967#.VwxZbNT3aK0

=== What to Bring ===


We might still need traction - either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike: 

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Crawford Depot parking lot (NOT THE AMC's HIGHLAND CENTER) which is located on the south side of Route 302 about 200 yards east of the AMC's Highland Center. According to Google Maps this spot is about 160 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 35 minutes to drive there.

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

a link to the frisbee golf map is here for you to print out:

course map

After lunch the option is open for any diehards to hike some trails.

results.description:
This is a 5 mile loop around Hickory Hills Forest and Lunenburg conservation land. It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. Walk over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots, sneakers are not recommended.  We do encounter streams, wet leaves and rocks, from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags. 

NEW !!!!!! PLEASE TAKE NOTE: The time has changed and sneakers are not recommended.
Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:00 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.
results.name: Trail Hiking, Rolling terrrain

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $75 or $90 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
We will be working through Meyer text on the Dussack.  We will also look at how these techniques apply to  One-handed or arming sword.

We are going to interpret Joachim Meyer’s Dussak.  The translation we will use is in

The Art of Combat: A German Martial Arts Treatise of 1570 (Hardcover)

http://www.amazon.com/gp/offer-listing/1848327781/ref=sr_1_5_twi_2_har_olp?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1434813702&sr=1-5&keywords=meyer

with additional material from Meyer’s 1560 work

https://sites.google.com/site/jochimmeyer1560/home/Meyer_1560_english_Maurer_2012.pdf?attredirects=0&d=1

From Jakob Sutor’s “New Illustrated Fechtbuch” of 1612

https://docs.google.com/file/d/0Bxqzt-jcOCFsT19Xa1Q2QXltWm8/edit

Finally some from

Cod.Guelf.83.4 Aug.8º


http://www.thearma.org/Manuals/Codex-Guelf-83.4-Aug-8f-translation.pdf

results.description:
Do you work with a ton of people (especially ones with emotional challenges)?  Or perhaps you're in other people's energies all day. 

If you're doing anything where you are dipping into the energy world or working with other people, you need to know how to clear your energy field. 

Symptoms of a Gummed-up Energy Field 

1) Feeling tired all the time 
2) Headaches 
3) Confusion and Inability to Focus 
4) Unexpected or unexplained reactions from others 
5) Inability to access any of the Chakra centers 
6) Feeling unsafe or ungrounded 
7) Feeling weak or victimized for no good reason 
8) Sudden shifts in sense of well being 
9) Intuition either on overdrive or shut down 
10) Disrupted sleep patterns

Energetic hygiene is of critical importance. You wouldn't go weeks without a shower, you shouldn't go weeks without clearing your energy field. You won't believe the difference in how you feel when you start doing this regularly. 

You'll Learn:

1) Several different ways to clear your energy field 
2) Multiple ways to clear your home and/or work space 
3) Good energetic hygiene practices 
4) Boundaries to maintain your energetic clarity


COST:  $10.00 
To Register, please use this link:  Paypal.me/KelleSparta/10 
If you can't use this link, please email me at [masked] for other payment options.  Registrations aren't confirmed until payment is received. 

PLEASE ARRIVE 10-15 minutes EARLY - We will be setting intentional space at 10:00AM and the doors will close to new arrivals at that time.   

Don't Wait To Register - Our classes tend to sell out well in advance of the class time.  We only have room for 14 people, so the space goes quickly.  Register now to save your space.

Parking is readily available on our street. Because it's a Sunday, resident parking isn't enforced, so you can park in any legal space.  

Please do not wear fragrances! Kelle is allergic to most fragrances (yes, even essential oils), so please don't wear them.

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE COMPLETE HIKE DESCRIPTION BEFORE SIGNING UP!  Remember, we are all hiking at our own risk and it is up to you to judge your abilities and to prepare accordingly.

This is the third in our series of hikes at the Breakheart Reservation and includes trails not included on the other hikes.  This hike will take us an estimated two hours and is approximately 3 - 3.5 miles long.  There are three different aspects of this hike which includes river views, Breakheart Hill and an overview of the area around Route 1 (look, Kelly's Roast Beef!), and of both the upper and lower ponds, and of course, a lot of walking in the woods.


This hike is a little less challenging than the previous Ridge Trail hike, but the terrain is quite varied with some steep angles, raised roots, plenty of rocks, and possibly mud.   Hiking boots with good traction and support are strongly recommended.  As always, there are a number of points where our hike intersects or parallels the main road should you need or want to leave the trails for any reason.

Upon completion of the hike, participants can enjoy lunch together afterward at a restaurant on nearby Route 1.  There is plenty of parking by the Vo Tech School on the wooded side of the lot.  We will meet by the large metal gate at the entrance of the park.  If it rains, the event is cancelled and may rescheduled at a later date.

People on the waitlist should consider themselves "on the hike" as there are a lot of last minute cancellations and no-shows, as with many meet ups, sadly.  Looking forward to meeting you, sharing the beauty of this local gem, and taking to the trails!
results.name: Hiking the trails of the Breakheart Reservation - River, Hill, and Ponds Hike

results.description:
On May 1st 2016, the MIT Co-Design Studio team, Research Action Design, Intelligent Mischief , the Detroit Community Technology Project, and Boston Civic Media (bostoncivic.media) are calling on YOU to join us at the Boston Co-op DiscoTech. The Co-op DiscoTech (shorthand for a Cooperative Economy Discovering Technology fair) is an event designed for people of all backgrounds and skill levels to learn about how technology can be used to support the growth of the cooperative economy – worker-owned cooperatives, consumer cooperatives, housing cooperatives, and more!

If you’d like to know more, or you want to present your work or host a workshop at the DiscoTech, please contact Katie: [masked]

More info: http://codesign.mit.edu/discotechs

*NOTE: *If you’d like to eat free, delicious food when you come to the DiscoTech, *please RSVP here: **https://www.eventbrite.com/e/coop-discotech-boston-tickets-23441822121***

We’ll focus on creating welcoming spaces where a wide range of people (not just techies!) will feel welcome sharing and learning about each other’s experiences with cooperatives: worker-owned co-ops, consumer co-ops, housing co-ops, hybrid cooperatives, co-op support organizations … pretty much anything that has to do with the cooperative economy! We’re also inviting cooperative organizations, technologists, developers, and designers to come to the DiscoTech to learn, teach, sprint, hack, meet up, explore projects, and build community together.

We’ll dive in deep to understand worker cooperative tools, systems, and histories, through speakers, skillshares, workshops, and activities open to all. We’ll also get hands-on with tools and approaches that can strengthen worker, consumer, housing, and hybrid cooperatives. We’ll link existing co-ops, technologists, designers, and community organizers to strengthen our strategies and tools for a cooperative future!


After/Party at Make/Shift, 7pm+
results.how_to_find_us: Park Street T stop
results.name: Co-Op DiscoTech (and AfterParty)

results.description:
May 1st is Founder's Day within Tall Clubs International. (Kae Sumner Einfeldt's birthday) So for this month we've moved our standard "One More Time" monthly Friday night dinner to a Sunday brunch so we can participate in the toast to Kae.

The Deluxe Station Diner is located in Newton Center in the old train station building that's right at the Newton Center T stop.  It has the right balance of ambiance and good food/drinks, reasonably priced with a very comfortable feel to it; warm and friendly.  We sit at the bar if we have a small group.  We grab a table  for a larger group.

For brunch they do great Bloody Mary's and multiple flavores of Mimosas. Plus of course all the standard breakfast/brunch foods.  Everything we've tried there has tasted great!

Several large municipal parking lots are nearby. Meters are free after 6:00 pm and on Sundays.

MBTA: Green Line, “D” train, Newton Center stop. When you come up the stairs from the train tracks, you are on Union Street. The diner is inside the old brownstone Union Station.

Bus #52 from Watertown Square (www.mbta.com for schedule and exact route).

Driving:

From the Mass Pike (east-bound):
Take exit 17 and make your first right after the set of lights, onto Centre Street. Follow Centre Street approximately three miles through. Take a left onto Langley Road and park in the parking lot on the left or park any where on Langley Road. (There are many other different options to park around Newton Center).

From the Mass Pike (west-bound):
Take exit 17 and go straight off the ramp. After the ramp, you will go through two sets of lights. After the second set, turn left at the sign that says "Newton Centre/Boston." You will be making a 180-degree turn and should stay in the right lane. Take your first right after the 180-degree turn onto Centre Street. Follow Centre Street approximately three miles through. Take a left onto Langley Road and park in the parking lot on the left or park any where on Langley Road. (There are many other different options to park around Newton Center).

From Route 9:
Take the Newton Center/Centre Street Exit. Follow Centre Street until you reach Beacon Street. Take a right onto Beacon Street and park in the parking lot on your left or on Beacon Street.

results.description:
Many prominent international newspapers in [masked] reviewed this Orwellian Sci Fi Book about China. Let's find out why they thought it important.


The author is a Hong Kong native carrying a UK Passport, though he lives in Beijing, Taiwan and Hong Kong. Needless to say, the book is banned in China.


Amazon Blurb:  An entire month has gone missing from Chinese records. No one has any memory of it, and no one seems to care except for a small circle of friends who will stop at nothing to get to the bottom of the sinister cheerfulness and amnesia that have possessed the nation. When they kidnap a high-ranking official and force him to reveal all, what they learn—not only about their leaders, but also about their own people—stuns them to the core.

Links to some reviews:

NYTimes: On the Party Circuit, and Upsetting the Party


NPR : "Chan's book is an urgent clarion call for people in every country to treasure their individuality, and to reject leaders who promise temporary happiness in exchange for total freedom."


LA Times : "... a consideration of the way forgetting influences polity, and in the face of overwhelming options, we lose sight of what we need."


Wall Street Journal


BBC

The Guardian

results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$2/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $15/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!

results.description:
WARNING: the meet up time now varies from week to week. if you can't make it, make sure you change your RSVP to No, such that someone else can take your spot.

We have rented 3 badminton courts at the BU Fitness & Recreation Center (regulation full sized courts).  The BU facility is immaculate and a fantastic place to play.


The fee (payable online when you RSVP) gets you into the BU Fitness & Recreation Center to play badminton for an hour and a half.  Part of the fee is for the court time and the rest is for your meetup group to cover other expenses, i.e. rackets, shuttlecocks/birdies, meetup.com fees. All fees collected go to pay the Group's expenses.

We have rackets and shuttles for everyone!

Expect to play doubles. The host can help to match up pairs but members are free to join in any game they want.  The courts are reserved only for Boston Badminton members.

Before asking a question, please read through the following FAQs:

Q: The meetup is full, can I come regardless and pay at the event?
A: No, there is limited space to make sure everyone gets to play. A few spots typically open up before the event.

Q: It's my first time, how do I find you?
A: Go to the BU Fitness & Recreation Center reception (see directions below), and tell them you're here with Boston Badminton. They'll tell you where the courts are, check you're on the list, and make you sign a waiver. The meeting point is on the courts.

Q: I am a BU student, do I get a discount?
A: No, BU charges us the same regardless of whether participants are at BU or not.


Directions:
Please click here for a google map to The BU Fitness & Recreation Center.  The easiest way to get to the FitRec center from within Boston is to take the Green Line (B)-Boston College to Saint Paul St.  Parking is limited but available.  Please click here for parking information.

Plan to grab a drink locally after if we have interest.

The club has full locker room and shower facilities.

Note: In addition to agreeing to the Meetup's Liability Waiver, all members must sign a Waiver of Liability Form in order to use BU's courts. This form is available at the front desk at the FitRec center.  We may ask you for your full name in order to help BU and the meetup comply with the liability procedures.

Let me know if you have any questions and I hope to see you there!

Liability Waiver

By attending a Boston Badminton meetup, you hereby agree to the terms of the following Liability Waiver:

The purpose of the following Liability Waiver is to protect Boston Badminton meetup members and group leaders from liability in case of accident or injury. All members must agree to the Liability Waiver in order to participate in the group and its activities.

As part of my membership to Boston Badminton on Meetup.com (hereinafter “Boston Badminton”), I hereby freely and voluntarily agree to the following Release, Acknowledgment of Risk, and Waiver of Liability:

In consideration of the opportunity to participate in events, activities, classes, and programs conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates in any venue, and to use equipment located therein, I, on behalf of myself and my minor children, do hereby release, hold harmless and forever discharge and agree not to sue Boston Badminton and its trustees, officers, agents, founders, members, volunteers and employees (together, "Meetup.com Group") from any and all claims, responsibilities or liabilities for injury or damages resulting from or arising out of my or my family’s use of, presence in, or participation in activities conducted at any venue rented or owned by Boston Badminton, whether or not caused by the ordinary negligence of Boston Badminton. I understand, recognize and acknowledge that certain activities conducted by Boston Badminton or taking place in venues rented or owned by Boston Badminton are potentially hazardous. I also acknowledge that it is my responsibility to follow instructions for any activity or use of equipment, and to seek help from the volunteers if I have any questions. I further understand that, notwithstanding precautions taken by Boston Badminton, sports and fitness activities involve a risk of injury and/or death. I/we are voluntarily participating in these activities and using equipment and machinery with knowledge of the dangers involved. I hereby agree to expressly assume and accept any and all risks associated with my participation in activities conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates. I have read the foregoing and hereby agree to be bound by same.

results.description:
From Publishers Weekly
Today's kids are increasingly disconnected from the natural world, says child advocacy expert Louv ( Childhood's Future; Fatherlove; etc.), even as research shows that "thoughtful exposure of youngsters to nature can... be a powerful form of therapy for attention-deficit disorder and other maladies." Instead of passing summer months hiking, swimming and telling stories around the campfire, children these days are more likely to attend computer camps or weight-loss camps: as a result, Louv says, they've come to think of nature as more of an abstraction than a reality. Indeed, a 2002 British study reported that eight-year-olds could identify Pokémon characters far more easily than they could name "otter, beetle, and oak tree." Gathering thoughts from parents, teachers, researchers, environmentalists and other concerned parties, Louv argues for a return to an awareness of and appreciation for the natural world. Not only can nature teach kids science and nurture their creativity, he says, nature needs its children: where else will its future stewards come from? Louv's book is a call to action, full of warnings—but also full of ideas for change. Agent, James Levine. (May 20)
Copyright © Reed Business Information, a division of Reed Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Somerville IFED-- IFED stands for International Family Equality Day and it is celebrated around the world on the first Sunday in May. This is the 5th year of this annual celebration and the second year it will be in Somerville. IFED celebrates all the different kinds of families with the goal of increasing the international visibility of LGBTQ families. By celebrating International Family Equality Day, The Rainbow Initiative, Family Equality Council and our partners across the globe raise awareness among politicians and the general public about the need for equal treatment and recognition for all families, regardless of the sexual orientation or gender identity of their family’s members. This event is free and open to everyone to enjoy. The celebration is held in Seven Hills Park (behind the Somerville Theater), on Sunday, May 1st from 1 to 5 pm. Somerville IFED Line up:

results.description:
Home Owners, Gardeners, Landscape Professionals and Native Plant Lovers Learn how to control nonnative, invasive plants in your yard, town and watershed in a workshop that will be presented at three different locations: Canton Public Library (April 9), Pembroke Public Library (April 16) and The Spire in Plymouth (May 1). 

To register, go to: <a>www.watershedaction.org.</a> This three-hour workshop is designed for people looking for basic information, how-to advice and local expertise. It will include an Overview of nonnative, invasive plant characteristics and control, Case Studies, and How to Move Forward in controlling target plants. 

If you have Phragmites blocking your view, knotweed taking over your yard, purple loosestrife spreading along your pond or stream, or other invasive plants that are out of control, you will enjoy this workshop. 

Amanda Crouch-Smith, a Professional Wetland Scientist and Certified Invasive Plant Manager, will cover the basics from the characteristics of nonnative, invasive plants and the worst of them in southeastern Massachusetts, to prioritization of species and control options, including mechanical, chemical and biological choices. 

Several local property owners will share their experiences with small-scale projects fighting species of local concern. Lessons and advice will be applicable to a wide variety of other invasive plants. 

Finally, learn how to move forward with control projects – what regulatory processes might be required, how to find assistance and identify possible funding opportunities, and what nearby community or watershed projects exist to join for results that go beyond a single property’s boundaries.

 Attendees will receive several useful resources, including a guide to identifying nonnative, invasive species in Massachusetts, a checklist of steps to follow, and a list of useful websites and publications. Register soon and save $5! The early bird fee is $15. Workshops will be $20 at the door.
To register, go to: http://watershedaction.org, or leave a message for the event manager at:[masked]-0769. The workshops are organized by Watershed Action Alliance of Southeastern Massachusetts, a coalition of ten watershed and two pond associations, which works to advocate and educate for healthy watersheds and clean, plentiful, and free-flowing water. Sponsors include Island Foundation, North and South Rivers Watershed Association, Jones River Watershed Association, Six Ponds Improvement Association, Save the Bay – Narragansett Bay and Herring Ponds Watershed Association. The Plymouth workshop is hosted by the Town of Plymouth’s Open Space Committee.
results.name: Learn How to Identify and Control Invasive Species

results.description:
On Sunday, May 1, join us for a talk with Marshall Ganz, Senior Lecturer in Public Policy at the Harvard Kennedy School about how we can translate our values into collective action.

Marshall Ganz grew up in Bakersfield, California, where his father was a Rabbi and his mother, a teacher. He entered Harvard College in the fall of 1960. He left a year before graduating to volunteer with the 1964 Mississippi Summer Project. He found a “calling” as an organizer for the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, and, in the fall of 1965, joined Cesar Chavez in his effort to unionize California farm workers. During 16 years with the United Farm Workers he gained experience in union, political, and community organizing, became Director of Organizing, and was elected to the national executive board on which he served for 8 years. During the 1980s, he worked with grassroots groups to develop new organizing programs and designed innovative voter mobilization strategies for local, state, and national electoral campaigns. In 1991, in order to deepen his intellectual understanding of his work, he returned to Harvard College and, after a 28-year "leave of absence," completed his undergraduate degree in history and government. He was awarded an MPA by the Kennedy School in 1993 and completed his PhD in sociology in 2000. As senior lecturer in public policy at the Kennedy School of Government, he teaches, researches, and writes on leadership, organization, and strategy in social movements, civic associations, and politics. He has published in the American Journal of Sociology, American Political Science Review, American Prospect,Washington Post, Los Angeles Times and elsewhere. His newest book, Why David Sometimes Wins: leadership, organization and strategy in the California farm worker movement was published in 2009, earning the Michael J. Harrington Book Award of the American Political Science Association. He was awarded an honorary doctorate in divinity by the Episcopal Divinity School in 2010.

***Seats are very limited.

results.description:
Have you ever tried to make change and then found yourself falling back again into old patterns?  

Does the fear of not being good enough, or losing what you have, or not knowing what comes next stop you in your tracks?


Then you're running into resistances!

Resistances are sneaky little thought-worms that get into your brain and shut you down from the process of change.  In this class, we'll lay out the major types of resistances and how to break through them into the change you desire.

This class is for those who are serious about making change but who keep getting in their own way when they try to do it.

You'll Learn:

• What the major types of resistances are - both mental/emotional and energetic

• The secret to clearing each type of resistance so you can soar forward

• The one major pitfall that you REALLY want to avoid when trying to make change in your life.


Don't miss this powerful life-changing class.  It will blow you away and get you moving forward quickly.


PLEASE ARRIVE 10-15 minutes EARLY - We will be setting intentional space at 2:00PM and the doors will close to new arrivals at that time.  

Don't Wait To Register - Our classes tend to sell out well in advance of the class time.  We only have room for 15 people, so the space goes quickly.  Register now to save your space.

Parking is readily available on our street.  Because it's a Sunday, resident parking isn't enforced, so you can park in any legal space.  

Please do not wear fragrances!  Kelle is allergic to most fragrances (yes, even essential oils), so please don't wear them.

results.description:
When a cookbook on Amazon boasts a 4.5 star rating (out of 5), that is pretty impressive. Upon closer inspection, you look and see that over 3,000 people reviewed the book — that makes you stop and pay attention. Or in my case, make an impulse purchase and feature it for one of our feasts (even before looking at one recipe)! Yeah, sometimes I tend to go with my gut. *wink*

And let me say—WOW—this book is incredible! I'm so happy to be adding it to my cookbook collection. 

Colorful language aside, the recipes are super creative and inspiring.


Let's come together for another feast and play with our veggies! If you want to order the book for your library, click HERE.


Note :: You do not have to buy a copy of the cookbook in order to participate this event. Check your local library or ask a friend to borrow their copy.

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

INSTRUCTIONS :: How the Cookbook Club Works

1. Join our Meetup group! All cooking levels are welcome. Don't be shy. You're in good company.

2. RSVP via Meetup. Note :: Our feasts are the 1st Sunday of every month, focusing on a different cookbook, author, or blog.

3. Grab yourself a copy of this month's featured cookbook, "Thug Kitchen" (ask your library, borrow from a friend, order online or purchase at a local retailer) and experiment with a few of the recipes.

4. Pick a minimum of 1 recipe that you will make for our feast. Be sure to read through all of the instructions to make sure you have the proper tools, dishes, and ingredients. (I made that mistake at a previous feast.)

5. In the comments section below, share which recipe you will be bringing, and the page number (this info will help me as I'm preparing a new idea for our feast events). I'll keep track of what everyone is bringing and make sure we don't have any overlaps. Note :: Pick a backup recipe in case your 1st choice is already taken.

6. Day of the event (or the day before). Prepare your recipe according to the directions provided in the cookbook. Source ingredients locally, if you can. As tempting as it might be to alter the recipe or make a substitution, please follow the instructions as closely as possible. This will allow the group to truly experience the author's array of recipes. Note :: There's no need to double or triple the recipe. There will be more than enough food for everyone to sample.

7. Come with an open mind and empty stomach. Get ready for a fun time with really amazing people. I honestly believe that we are a bunch of great home cooks AND are a blast to hang out with. Together we will feast on your wonderful food and share our experiences with one another. We learn a lot from each other and go home with new ideas. Feel free to bring your cookbook in order to highlight certain pages or make notes on recipes you especially loved. Post-it notes, journals and pencils are provided.

8. If you feel inspired to bring fancier serving dishes (for photos), I won't stop you! But it's not essential . . . just slightly more fun.

9. Don't forget to bring a few small storage containers for leftovers. You'll have the best lunch that following Monday . . . I promise.

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

WHAT'S INCLUDED :: (Stuff you don't have to worry about.)

1. Tables + Chairs

2. Linens, Tableware + Utensils

3. Extra Serving Utensils

4. Non-Alcoholic Beverages: water, fresh coffee (with caffeine), tea, and hot cocoa. Note :: If you want to bring wine or beer to share, please feel free to do so!

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

TIPS + IDEAS :: (From our fellow cookbook collectors)

1. Go out of your comfort zone. Try a new technique or work with ingredients you've never used before. Bring the final dish, regardless of the outcome—good or bad—and let everyone learn from your experience! (Thank you Renee for this suggestion.)

2. There's no guarantee your dish will remain HOT by the time we are ready to eat. Consider recipes that not only travel well, but also can be served at room temperature. Either way, you're welcome to bring your own heating elements, crock pots, or warmers. I just can't guarantee there will always be an outlet accessible.

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

IN CLOSING . . .

Many of the members in this groups are super excited to be participating in our feasts. So, if you're lucky enough to reserve a spot on the list . . . please be sure you can actually make it to the event. I wouldn't want spots to be inadvertently reserved, while there are other members willing to attend the event. Plus, it will help me get a more accurate head count for the venue (and for renting chairs). Thanks so much! —Jessica
results.name: May feast — Thug Kitchen *Vegetarian Event*

results.description:
Join us in reading and discussion around Racism without Racists: Color-Blind Racism and the Persistence of Racial Inequality in America, by Eduardo Bonilla-Silva (recommended: get 4th Edition, which adds a new chapter).


See the lower part of this description for our plan to share in the discussion of this book.

Description from Amazon:

Eduardo Bonilla-Silva’s acclaimed Racism without Racists documents how, beneath our contemporary conversation about race, lies a full-blown arsenal of arguments, phrases, and stories that whites use to account for—and ultimately justify—racial inequalities. This provocative book explodes the belief that America is now a color-blind society.


.......................

We will continue the dynamic of being responsible to present a part of the book. While we will all do our best to read the whole book, we ask that readers commit to reading Chapter 1: The Strange Enigma of Race in Contemporary America (17 pages) and Chapter 10 (or 11): "The (Color-Blind) Emperor Has No Clothes - Exposing the Whiteness of Color Blindness (10 pages). In addition, each of us will choose a chapter to present about to the group. Plan for about five minutes of time. Here are some ideas of things you might include in your presentation (choose any or do something else!):


• Summarize the chapter.

• What was especially important for you about this chapter?

• What questions did the chapter raise for you?

• Share a quote from the chapter.

• Make a connection to another book or resource.

• Create and share an artistic response to the chapter.

Please post the number for your additional chapter in the comments section below.  You can view what people have picked so far here.


Because of space limitations, a maximum of 16 people can attend. Please be mindful when you RSVP that a waitlist is likely and update your RSVP if you're unable to attend or commit to reading the book.

See you then!
results.name: Knapsack Book Discussion: "Racism without Racists"

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Potbelly Sandwich Shop behind CVS (on Somerville Ave) 

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. You can easily spot Potbelly Sandwich Shop on side entrance when you arrive at top of escalator at Porter Square Station. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
All the Light We Cannot See by Anthony Doer

WINNER OF THE PULITZER PRIZE
From the highly acclaimed, multiple award-winning Anthony Doerr, the beautiful, stunningly ambitious instant New York Times bestseller about a blind French girl and a German boy whose paths collide in occupied France as both try to survive the devastation of World War II.

Marie-Laure lives with her father in Paris near the Museum of Natural History, where he works as the master of its thousands of locks. When she is six, Marie-Laure goes blind and her father builds a perfect miniature of their neighborhood so she can memorize it by touch and navigate her way home. When she is twelve, the Nazis occupy Paris and father and daughter flee to the walled citadel of Saint-Malo, where Marie-Laure’s reclusive great-uncle lives in a tall house by the sea. With them they carry what might be the museum’s most valuable and dangerous jewel.

In a mining town in Germany, the orphan Werner grows up with his younger sister, enchanted by a crude radio they find. Werner becomes an expert at building and fixing these crucial new instruments, a talent that wins him a place at a brutal academy for Hitler Youth, then a special assignment to track the resistance. More and more aware of the human cost of his intelligence, Werner travels through the heart of the war and, finally, into Saint-Malo, where his story and Marie-Laure’s converge.

Doerr’s “stunning sense of physical detail and gorgeous metaphors” (San Francisco Chronicle) are dazzling. Deftly interweaving the lives of Marie-Laure and Werner, he illuminates the ways, against all odds, people try to be good to one another. Ten years in the writing, a National Book Award finalist, All the Light We Cannot See is a magnificent, deeply moving novel from a writer “whose sentences never fail to thrill” (Los Angeles Times).

Location:

Vincent's place is near Porter Square, in Somerville (The address will be sent to attendees.) It is less than a 10-min walk from the Red Line and the 77, 83 and 87 buses stop nearby. Street parking (free) is also available but carpooling is encouraged =)
results.name: May Book Club--  All the Light We Cannot See

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

Dear Greater Boston Permaculture Guild -
you might not know this, but Boston Food Forest Coalition is the organization that has been hosting this meetup (thanks to Allison and Utah, founding members of BFFC). 

This meetup is a vital part of strengthening our community of practice, sharing skills and weaving relationships - all core to the mission of the Boston Food Forest Coalition, which has also been hosting the only PDC in the Boston area (taught by Lisa Fernandes and Jesse Watson from Portland's Resilience Hub).

Boston Food Forest Coalition exists because of dedicated volunteers and operates on a shoe-string budget, we need your help and love if we are to grow and sustain this vital activity in the Greater Boston area.

So it is with great excitement that we invite you to join us on MAY 1st for our first ever fundraiser. Hope you will come and invite your permie friends!

Details:

--Deepening Our Roots--

Sunday, May 1st, 5-7pm

Please join BFFC friends, to share food gardens and giving!

We will be sharing our goals, along with rare plants

Come and learn, bid on rare plants and sustainable auction items:
Herb spiral, Sheet Mulch bed, an oil infusion party,
Grow microgreens party, wattle fencing, an apple tree guild & more! 

Farm-to-table and local foods, beers, wines thanks to Bonnie Rovics and Onsite Organics!

We appreciate whatever level your giving allows:

Individual ticket $25

Membership and ticket $40 (includes tee shirt)

Canopy Sponsorship $125 (includes plant + t-shirt)

Guild Sponsorship $250 (includes rare plant + t-shirt)

Come and learn about food forest gardens, bid on rare plants and unique auction items to help the Boston Food Forest Coalition create and support more forest gardens in Boston

http://www.bostonfoodforest.org/spring-fundraiser-2016/

results.description:
Meet other members for a brief happy hour mingle.  An icebreaker will be provided to held facilitate mingling. Then you'll be seated for your series of four minute "mini-dates." On your dating card that you receive at check-in, you'll select who you wish to see again. You can choose Dating or Friendship as your preferred connection.

We will collect everyone's dating cards at the end of the event and email you your mutual matches within 48 hours.

While this event is geared towards helping people meet potential romantic matches, you can also mingle with all the guests and find new friends as well.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/
results.how_to_find_us: Enter at The Hawthorne Building, the large glass doors to the left of H&R Block.

results.description:
The book for this meeting will be Nectar in a Sieve by Kamala Markandaya.  Finishing the book is not required, please join us regardless (but don't hate us if we talk about the ending....).

Our next meeting will be on a Sunday evening - May 1 at 5:30 PM, at Redstone Grill in Burlington, MA.  Please RSVP for this meetup by April 25 so I can make a reservation.


Next month's book:  we don't have one yet!   So, bring a couple of recommendations to the meeting, and we will choose the next book together.

Logistics:  In the next month or two, once we have solidified into a core group for the club, we might migrate to an email list or some other platform to manage the group.  If you have recommendations or feel strongly about sticking with Meetup, please message me.

Hope to see everyone at our May meeting!

Kelly
results.name: May meeting - Nectar in a Sieve

results.description:
“We can destroy what we have written, but we cannot unwrite it.” ―from A Clockwork Orange 

A vicious fifteen-year-old "droog" is the central character of this 1963 classic, whose stark terror was captured in Stanley Kubrick's visceral film of the same title.

In Anthony Burgess's nightmare vision of the future, where criminals take over after dark, the story is told by the central character, Alex, who talks in a brutal invented slang that brilliantly renders his and his friends' social pathology. A Clockwork Orange is a dark fable about good and evil, and the meaning of human freedom. When the state undertakes to reform Alex—to "redeem" him—the novel asks, "At what cost?"

We will discuss the edition that includes the controversial last chapter not published in the first edition and Burgess's introduction "A Clockwork Orange Resucked."
results.name: Burgess: A Clockwork Orange

group.name: Classic Books: A Book Club for Voracious Readers

results.description:
Join The Oldest Established Permanent Floating Community Walk in Cambridge 

For the 200th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.


Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 5/1  6:30

results.description:
Dear hearts :) 

I'd like to let you know about our bonus of free Usui Reiki Level 1 mass attunement every 1st of each month. This free mass attunement is also actually given as our social service for those who cannot afford Reiki workshop fee but are willing to use Reiki channeling ability to help him/herself and others.

You do not need to register in advance to receive this mass attunement, just be ready during the schedule of 6.30pm local time. More details on this below.

Please understand that this free attunement is not Reiki Tummo attunement, it is Usui Reiki Level 1 attunement. In term of the attunement results, it is not the same as Reiki Tummo attunement because the Usui Reiki attunements will only open upper half of your main energy channel/sushumna (from crown chakra to heart chakra) while Reiki Tummo attunements will open the whole sushumna from crown chakra up to base chakra. However, this free Usui Reiki Level 1 attunement is given remotely by Mr. Irmansyah Effendi by means of Reiki Tummo attunement techniques, so the result is somehow better than traditional Usui Reiki attunement results. 

For more detail information about the difference between Usui Reiki and Reiki Tummo attunement results, please use your yahoo email address to sign in to this group web page (http://groups.yahoo.com/mygroups) and then visit the file section of this group or click:
http://health.groups.yahoo.com/group/Kundalini_Reiki/files/DRAWINGS_PHOTOS_ILLUSTRATIONS/ and the file name is: AttunementComparisonUsuiReikiTummo.gif
You are welcome to explore and study other drawings there and put questions on this list.

For more detail information about Reiki Tummo You can also buy Reiki Tummo book ("REIKI TUMMO: An Effective Technique For Health and Happiness" is written by the founder and Grandmaster of Reiki Tummo, Irmansyah Effendi, MSc.) at www.amazon.com (ISBN:[masked])

Since it is given by means of Reiki Tummo attunement technique, the result is very good for cleansing your crown chakra, heart chakra as well as palm chakras and energy channels. All alumni of Reiki Tummo workshops from Padmacahaya or Padmajaya are entitled to join and receive this free mass attunement as Reiki Tummo attunement (because you already received one before). 

Please read the instruction below on DISTANT ATTUNEMENT PREPARATION. Also since the main benefit of the attunement is to help your heart get better connection to Divine Love and Light so your heart can be opened and cleansed better by Divine Love and Light then we suggest you to also do OPEN HEART PRAYER/MEDITATION daily before and after the attunement. Please read more information below. 

May you enjoy and get benefit from this mass attunement. 

Much Love and Light for your beautiful hearts, :) 

----------------------------------------------------------
DISTANT ATTUNEMENT PREPARATION
Note: No need to register in advance, just be ready during the attunement.

WHAT TO DO FOR A DISTANT ATTUNEMENT

1. You do not need to register to receive this free mass attunement of Usui Reiki Level 1. Just prepare your self at the day of the attunement (1st of each month) 
2. No need to adjust your local time any longer. The attunement has been programmed to be received every 1st of each month at 6.30 PM YOUR OWN LOCAL TIME, where ever you are, for 15 minutes duration. 
3. Please study how to do Self Healing/Treatment with Reiki. You can find this in some web pages or in some Reiki books. You do need to do self healing right away after the attunement is finished to make good use of the attunement energy flow that is still working on you even though the attunement is over already. Please see Note below for suggested hand positions during self healing. 
4. On the attunement day, try to get a room where you will not be disturbed. The attunement will take about 15 minutes. It is best to have a room in which the light is not too bright. If possible, have new age music and incense or aroma therapy ready. Dim light and music will help you to get relaxed easily. The incense or aroma therapy will be needed to neutralize the negative energy that will come out of you during the attunement. Remember the attunement is also a cleansing process. 
5. About 30 minutes before the attunement, it is good to start doing simple and light exercises that move most parts of your body, but don't make yourself exhausted. Simply do exercise for about 30-60 seconds for each part of the body. This will help energy flow even better in your physical body layer. 
6. Since the attunement will help opening your heart connection to Divine energy, then for better result, we suggest you to do Open Heart Prayer/Meditation after doing simple exercises. That can be done about 15 minutes before the attunement. Please read more information on Open Heart Prayer/Meditation below. 
7. After the simple exercises and Open Heart Prayer, get relaxed, dim the light, and turn the music on. Light incense before the attunement starts. Sit on a chair; try to keep your spine straight without forcing it. Make sure that your legs are not crossed and it is better if both feet are grounded. Put both of your hands on your thighs with your palms facing upwards. Please don't fall asleep during the attunement! :) 
8. During the attunement, simply relax. Do not make any effort to concentrate. Do not practice any breathing technique. Try to be as still as possible and enjoy whatever happens. It is a good practice to always relaxed, smile at your heart and surrender to Divine Source of Love and Light during the attunement. Also be willing to open your heart to Divine Source to receive more Divine Love and Light during the attunement. It is all done by intention only and then relaxed, smile and enjoy the attunement process. DO NOT EXPECT anything to happen since this will make you are not relaxed anymore :) 
9. After the attunement, do a complete self-healing directly. Take your time and do it properly and enjoy with smile and happy feeling from your heart all the time. 
10. After self-healing, try to do the same simple exercises you did before the attunement to help your physical body absorb Reiki energy better.
11. Keep on doing self healing for at least 21 days. It is best to do it every day even after you pass the 21-days period to maintain your health and improve your energy. Also, since the main benefit of channeling Reiki energy is to open and cleanse our heart, then it is always better to do Open Heart Prayer also every day to cleanse and keep our heart open better for Divine Love and Light.

Note: 
1) Suggested hand positions for channeling Reiki energy during Self Healing are (3 minutes per position sequentially): 
FRONT OF THE BODY: Forehead/face, Cheeks, Throat, Upper chest, Lower chest, Stomach, Thighs, Knees, and Ankles
BACK OF THE BODY: Back of the head, Nape of the neck, Upper back, Lower back/waist, Buttocks, Back of thighs, Calves and Soles of the feet 
2) More detail and complete techniques about doing healing and other Reiki techniques will be taught in Reiki Tummo workshops. Visit www.padmacahaya.com or www.padmacahaya.org for more information.
3) Please feel free to share your experiences after the attunement and doing Self Healing for 21 days and Open Heart Meditation every day.

----------------------------------------------------------
OPEN HEART PRAYER/MEDITATION
(By Irmansyah Effendi)

Each time we have negative emotion, we leave / deposit negativities within our heart. How many time a day we have negative emotions, even though we do not show them. To cleanse the heart further (bigger and deeper), the best way is to ask for blessing from the True Source of Love and Light. 

Before you start this prayer, you may need to write down the name of the people you don't like (you need to forgive), and for what you need to ask for forgiveness. You can replace the terminology “True Source” with any other terminology which you are more comfortable with / can relate better to.

STEPS:
(Follow your feeling while praying)
1. Touch your heart (center of your chest) with 1 or 2 fingers
2. Close your eyes
3. Relax
4. Smile
5. Smile to your heart sweetly and freely
6. Feel the nice feeling from your heart, smile and stay within that nice feeling along the prayer
7. Pray (from the heart with feeling and love): 
1) True Source, please bless our heart so that all arrogance be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
2) True Source, please bless our heart so that all selfishness be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
3) True Source, please bless our heart so that all anger be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
4) True Source, please bless our heart so that all envy and jealousy be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
5) True Source, please bless our heart so that all greediness and cunningness be removed, to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
6) True Source, please bless our heart to understand that peace, calmness and joy are better than negative emotions. We have to let go of all negative emotions toward others, so that You can bless our heart, to fill our heart with Your Love and Light, peace, calmness and joy. Please bless and help us to be able to forgive everyone sincerely.
{Now, forgive everyone sincerely, although the same person has been doing the same negative things repeatedly and is still doing it. Remember that keeping negative emotion in you will simply give you pressure and burdens.}
7) True Source, as we have forgiven everyone else, please bless our heart so that all hatred, sadness, resentment, disappointment and other negative emotions, be removed to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
8) True Source, please bless and help us to realize that You are All Loving and All Forgiving. Please bless and help us to realize all of our mistakes, be remorseful, and ask for forgiveness. 
{Now, realize all of your mistakes, be remorseful, and ask for forgiveness.}
9) True Source, as You have forgiven all of our mistakes, please bless our heart and whole being so that all fear, worry, and burdens because of those mistakes, be removed to be replaced with Your Love and Light.
10) True Source, please bless and help us to be able to stay within our heart, within Your Love and Light, to always be peaceful, calm, and joyful.
11) True Source, thank You for all of Your blessing, Love and Light.
12) Amen.

Note:
a. Since the most important benefit of Reiki attunement for our heart is to open and connecting our heart better to Divine Love and Light to cleanse our heart further, so for better results of Reiki attunement on your self and heart, it is suggested to do this Open Heart Prayer prior to receiving the attunement (say starting 2 weeks daily before the attunement) and every day after the attunement. 
b. The Open Heart Prayer CD in English or Indonesian language is available for purchase. 
c. More techniques and practice on opening and activating your heart can be learnt through Open Heart Workshop from Padmacahaya. For more information on Open Heart Workshop please visit http://openheartworkshops.com

results.description:
Meet other members for a brief happy hour mingle.  An icebreaker will be provided to held facilitate mingling. Then you'll be seated for your series of four minute "mini-dates." On your dating card that you receive at check-in, you'll select who you wish to see again. You can choose Dating or Friendship as your preferred connection.

We will collect everyone's dating cards at the end of the event and email you your mutual matches within 48 hours.

While this event is geared towards helping people meet potential romantic matches, you can also mingle with all the guests and find new friends as well.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

Vegetarian Sausage- caramelized onions, mushrooms
Cider Glazed Pork Belly Steamed Bun
Burnt Cheddar Polenta
Buttermilk Biscuits
Grilled Apple Salad - dijon, pickled shallots, crispy quinoa
Housemade Sauerkraut

Join us Sunday May 1st, at 6:30pm for our second dinner at Downeast Cider over in Charlestown. We will highlight the flavors found in the cider not only pairing out dishes with the cider but also using the beverages as ingredients for our food. Dinner will be family style, but instead of having a line buffet like the first dinner we will bring all the food to each table for more of an intimate meal with your friends and family.
Email me at [masked] or purchase your seat in advance here: http://www.tbdfoods.com/dine-with-us/sunday-dinner-at-downeast-5-1 to confirm your seat and I will send the address
