venue.address_1: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138
venue.name: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138

results.description:
The oldest, established, permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and environs.

Please join the Fresh Pond Community walkers + five other meetup groups for this delightful sunset walk. 

Let's join 20+ walkers and some other walking groups for:

Over 3 years of reliable walking

Please note that this walk does not start at the same place as the other Fresh Pond walk.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 5/1  6:30

results.description:
Join the Fresh Pond Walking Community for our regular Sunday walk around Fresh Pond.   

Let's join regular walkers from surrounding towns + members of five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 5/1  6:30

results.name: Drumming Circle

results.description:
Join us for a night of french dancing and contra dancing, Sunday May 1st, at 1950 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge MA.

Earlier that day, we'll have a Musician's Workshop from 3-5 pm at a Somerville residence nearby, $10-20, please come and rsvp here: https://www.facebook.com/events/165835043807490/ The evening's dances at the hall will be a hybrid contra dance and French bal folk dance party! No experience necessary, and no need to bring a partner. All dances will be accessible, and all steps will be taught. We'll do beautiful, trancey dances from Brittany in circles and spirals. We'll do raucously fun dances from Central France like bourree and chapelloise, and more! Come get a taste of the European bal folk experience! Stay tuned for some sample videos below. Caller: Susan Kevra
Music: Rachel Bell, Dave Langford, and Julie Vallimont Dance 7:30-10:30pm
Dessert Potluck during the break -- Bring something to share! **Please feel free to join us at 7:00 for a beginner's lesson if you're fresh to contra dancing! $5-12 sliding scale, as you're able. Bring someone new to Contra to the intro session and you both get passes for free admission to a future dance! Share the love. Public Transportation (recommended): We are across the street from the Porter Square Red Line stop.

Parking: Free street parking (meters and residential are open to all on Sundays). Don't park in the Shaw's parking lot because they tow.

See you there!
results.name: BIDA 1st Sunday Contra + French Dancing

results.description: Únete a nosotros para una clausura de el Descubriendo Historias Escondidas (Unlocking Silent Histories) exposición de la galeria, y un celebración nuestra viaje a el Museo Nacional del Indio Americano Smithsonian en septiembre. Disfrute de los artesanos de jazz de clase mundial, mientras vea la cultura Guatemalteca rural a través del lente de estudiantes de cine de 12 a 18 años de edad. Sea testigo de la videografía, dirección y edición aprendido en los talleres “Descubriendo Historias Escondidas” y el arte de los artesanos son de Guatemala.
results.name: Recepción de jazz de clausura: un vistazo de arte visual en la vida maya.

group.name: The Boston Spanish Language Meetup Group

results.description: Join us for a closure of the Unlocking Silent Histories: Weaving Maya Past & Present multimedia gallery exhibition. Enjoy world class jazz, while watching the rural Guatemalan culture through the lens of film students 12 to 18 years old Maya youth participating in the non profit Unlocking Silent Histories, browsing through Guatemala textiles made by indigenous women associated with (Maya Traditions, Worthy Village, & Maya Earth Coffee), and viewing the works of Guatemalan artists Byron Rabe & Gloria Cholotio. After the event, feel free to join us at Parish cafe for conversation about the Guatemalan-based nonprofits/artists and reflections on the event.
results.name: Closing Reception: Weaving Maya Past & Present

results.description: Join us Sunday for the acclaimed mediumship of Joanne Gerber at 7pm. This Spiritualist service includes a sharing inspirational message and spirit greetings by Joanne Gerber. Don't miss this opportunity to experience Joanne's work for spirit and you!

Lizard Lounge is a hip and eclectic live music club. After Easter dinner come hang out with,The Jeff Robinson Trio (14 years running!). Basically it's free verse poetry spoken to a beat of music, or just solo. Very hip, very creative! Sometime funny!

The Lizard Lounge has a full bar and 30 brews on tap. dinner available until midnight.
results.name: Hear a poetry slam!

results.description:
No one likes to be wrong. And nobody likes it when they have to bear the consequences of someone else being wrong. But it happens all the time - hey, even your illustrious organizer has done it*. But why are we so averse to it, when in fact it's the world's way of informing us and instilling us with knowledge and experience? "Wrongologist" Kathryn Schulz has some ideas:

Kathryn Schulz: On being wrong

So if we all face the face in the mirror and accept our frailty, can we move forward and become better, more rounded people? Not so fast, you may retort. Anyone in business or politics knows that being wrong can cost you your job, an election, or your reputation. It seems to be a prisoner's dilemma game where we can only win if we all collectively accept  that it's okay to be wrong, and if only one of us does so unilaterally, they lose double. Is there a way out of that trap? How would one go about making wrong the new hip thing? Do we all need to accept some uncertainty from one another if we're going to pave the way for nature's way of revealing the truth? Perhaps there's wrong and then there's wrong - what sort of wrongs are safer than others for having?


Join us for a lively discussion of hearing that buzzer go off with a big red X on the screen.

Hope to see you there :)

* Well, actually I thought I was wrong once, but I was mistaken :>

(Har har, yeah I stole that joke, and I know it's wrong :> )
results.name: On Being Wrong

Join us for this celebration of spring at the annual "Art in Bloom" exhibit and tea at the MFA.  We have tickets to the Elegant Tea served in the William I. Koch Gallery (Gallery 250).  Following the tea, we can enjoy touring the beautiful floral arrangements inspired by works of art at the MFA.  There are free tours offered, and floral arranging demonstrations.  It is fun to see how various garden clubs and professional floral designers interpret art with flowers.

Tickets to the tea are limited, but we have purchased  tickets for our group.  Payment is required to sign up.  This charge is for the tea, and it does not include museum admission.  Museum passes are available through public libraries...be sure to arrange in advance.  We also are likely to have a number of members attending and can often get some of the group in on memberships of those attending.  If you sign up, please comment below if you have an admission pass that will allow an extra person in.  


Some special activities during Art in Bloom exhibit:


Art in Bloom Tours 
10 am–3 pm 
Tour arrangements throughout the galleries.

Designing with Flowers

Continuous demonstrations of flower arranging for your home.

Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. 

• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal ("Boston 1 - Join us") or venmo (@boston1dboat).</a>

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1Ll2NR3MZbV3O7ZrmPdZsCbKRaC_G8KKa7lwBUlC59Pk/viewform?c=0&w=1">"Boston 1 e-waiver" 

• Make sure to check our Facebook,</a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab. 
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards. 

• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended. 

• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $5 flat rate. Weekdays $8 flat rate (in after 3pm). More details can be found here: http://bit.ly/1Nxv1lw.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

https://youtu.be/OndSmceU9R4

results.description:
Immersive theater popularity has made waves with a whole new generation of theater-goers… but hasn't theater always been "immersive"?  And how does this trend correlate to our new tech and social platforms? That's what we're discussing at our next meetup on April 4th at MIT. 

MIT Open Documentary Lab and StoryCode Boston present a brief historical overview of immersive storytelling in live performance followed by a deeper look at local productions of the immersive variety such as American Repertory Theater's Sleep No More, shows at OBERON, and more recently Natasha, Pierre & The Great Comet of 1812.

Johnathan Carr is resident filmmaker at the A.R.T. , film/media designer for theater, and organizer of StoryCode Boston. (Photo: Gretjen Helene Photography)
results.how_to_find_us: Enter MIT at 77 Mass Ave (Rogers Building), walk through lobby, and down a long hallway. At second stairwell (Building 4), turn right and walk down that hallway through Building 4 to Building 2. Room 105 is at the end of that hallway to the left.

results.description:
Do you often get stuck in conversations? Not know how to approach people at networking events?


Join Socializing for Justice for a  fast-paced, fun & interactive ProfDev (professional development training) on the Art of the Schmooze on Monday, May 2, 6:00 - 8:30 PM. 

Fee: $15 advance/$30 door is split with the trainer.
Limited space - register ahead of time 
Credit cards accepted online and at the door.
Newcomers always welcomed!

*This is a fragrance-free event. Please do not wear fragrances (scented lotions,  perfumes, etc.) or smoke just prior to attending. Thank you.*

Art of the Schmooze
Forming and cultivating relationships is at the heart of any successful fundraising campaign, volunteer drive, committee effort or community building activity. This training will give you the confidence to pursue your personal and professional goals - from the importance of shaking hands and making eye contact, to tips on the best opening line and how to exit a conversation gracefully. An amazing side benefit is that you'll learn how to create a welcoming community space by keeping an eye out for outliers, considering yourself a host instead of a guest and knowing how to compliment someone without "othering" them.

ABOUT OUR PRESENTER 
Robbie Samuels has been recognized as a networking expert by Inc. and Lifehacker, and profiled in Stand Out: How to Find Your Breakthrough Idea and Build a Following Around It by Dorie Clark. Since 2009, his engaging and fun presentations have helped a wide array of audiences increase their confidence when it comes to building their professional network and strong, welcoming communities. He passionately believes everyone should stop wasting time networking and shares how through his signature session, “Art of the Schmooze.” 

In 2006, he founded Socializing for Justice (SoJust.org) to build a cross-cultural, cross-issue progressive community and network in Boston based on the philosophies of abundance and radical inclusion. In 2011, in recognition of his social justice work, Boston City Council named his birthday “Robbie Samuels Day." Learn more about his work and get connected at www.RobbieSamuels.com. 

SCHEDULE
6:00-6:30 Socializing -  bring your own dinner
 6:30-8:30 Training and Q&A

*  DIRECTIONS - The NonProfit Center is located one block from South Station at 89 South Street. The Center is physically accessible through the main lobby.

HELP SPREAD THE WORD!
Invite friends to the Facebook event.
Join the SoJust Facebook group.

On Twitter? Follow @SoJust and SoJust's Co-Founder @RobbieSamuels. Don’t forget to tweet about this event using #SoJust and #profdev!


____________________________________________________

Socializing for Justice - www.sojust.org

SoJust hosts events that draw progressives of all stripes that share common values but may work on different issues. We host socials that allow for the possibility of cross-issue connections and run a monthly ProfDev Series which provides access to affordable professional development to increase our individual capacity for movement building.


With over 2900 members and nearly 10 years of creating a diverse cross-issue community in Boston (200+ events!), Socializing for Justice is the best place to find the great people, organizations and community you're looking for while putting the SOCIAL back in social justice.

YES, WE MEAN YOU. We've got members of all ages, races, genders, sexual orientations, levels of activism and professions. We hope you see someone like yourself and meet someone you otherwise wouldn't have.
results.name: ProfDev: Art of the Schmooze

results.description:
Participatory design is an approach to the ideation and brainstorming phases of a project, where the users you are designing for take an active role in co-designing the experience or solution for themselves. Whether designing for students, teachers, or other audiences, when we move past the challenge of designing for them and begin designing with them, we find the outcomes are more actionable and inspiring.. and more fun.

In this session we'll explore: 

• An introduction: What is Participatory Design?

• How can you use participatory design or co-design methods in your practice? What are some of the basic methods and activities designers and educators can use? 

• How do you choose what method to use, and when?

• What does it look like? We'll try out some hands-on examples in a mini workshop using some of these methods.

Thanks to Jen Briselli of Mad*Pow, who will be bringing her expertise and leading this Meetup.


There will be pizza!
results.name: Participatory Design: Engaging Your Audience Directly in the Design Process

results.description:
{Watch Finding Joe, a film about Joseph Campbell's conception of hero's journey, and reflect on how it relates to your own journey of personal transformation.} 

Our Topic This Evening

Tonight we get to not only learn about the concept of the hero's journey through the excellent documentary, Finding Joe, but also explore our own personal journeys as the heroes of our own lives. 

Here are the trailer and description from the film's official website:


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AudQbaFN6jU

In the early 20th century, while studying world mythology, Joseph Campbell discovered a pattern hidden in every story ever told and he called it “the hero's journey”. A truly inspirational film, Finding Joe takes us on the ultimate hero's journey: the journey of self discovery. As you slay dragons and uncover treasures, you just may find that the holy grail you seek is closer than you think.


Note: This is a longer HBS than usual to accommodate both the film screening and the discussion afterward. If you can't be there the whole time (or need to bring your dinner with you!) don't sweat it; just come for the parts you can. Roughly, it'll break down to:

6:30-7:55 - Watch film

7:55-8:10 - Snack break, welcome, introductions

8:10-9:30 - Reflect, discuss, and wrap up

To Prepare

Consider where you are, and where you've been, on the hero's journey:

1) Are you hearing a call to adventure? Facing test and trials? Returning home to share your story?

2) What journeys have you already taken? What journeys may still lie ahead?

3) Watch any of these clips for inspiration, or search the web for more information about Joseph Campbell and the hero's journey.

Our Leader This Evening

Anne Lafleur, MSW, is a PGN program leader and organizer of Heartbeat Salons in MetroWest Boston. She is a workshop facilitator, happiness consultant, and the Assistant Center Director at Common Street Spiritual Center. She blogs about love, emotion, and human connection at www.thegiftofhappiness.org.


Links

Most Important:   
  * Other, Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 
  * Join our Heart Conversation on FaceBook

For Newbies:

7:00 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

New intermediate kizomba 8 week program starts this Monday April 25th! You should know the basics already to attend this program, otherwise join our Wednesdays beginners class at 7pm.

If you are brand new to Kizomba then this is the time to get started. if you're not too sure about it then this is the time to find out for yourself. If you've been to a few classes then this is what you've been waiting for. Come find out why everyone is so excited.

- Professionally developed Kizomba instruction program created by world renowned dancer Manuel 'Dr Kizomba' Dos Santos.
- A series of classes that will follow a progression from week 1 till 8, covering the timing, rhythm and accent of the dance

- Being a program as opposed to a 'drop in' class we will be able to progress together through the weeks, mastering the feeling and art of Kizomba

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).
results.name: Boston Shorinji Kempo Open Dojo Event

It really is for anyone who’s curious. Whether you're interested in investigating Christianity, you are a new Christian, or you just want to brush up on the basics - this is for you.

Why and how should I read the Bible?

Cinco de Mayo!....because why not celebrate early.

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait a few minutes for people to show and make introductions, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.  We usually climb until 9-9:30-ish, but if you'd like to secure partner(s) who can come earlier or stay later, feel free to post to the comment section below.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.


For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing (if you are interested in both). For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Basic Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).
results.name: MetroRock Monday

results.description:
The Coolidge Corner Theatre is proud to welcome back Berklee College of Music Professor Sheldon Mirowitz and the Berklee Silent Film Orchestra for the world premiere of the Berklee Silent Film Orchestra’s (BSFO) new, original score to E.A. Dupont’s Weimar-era masterwork, Varieté(1925). This is the tenth original Berklee score the Coolidge has commissioned for our Sounds of Silents® program.

VARIETE TICKETS:  I strongly encourage you to purchase tickets in Advance.  This event almost always sells out well ahead of time.

About Varieté

Silent film giant Emil Jannings stars in this wrenching tale of love and lust, set in a circus, with trapeze artists and murder.  Known as Jealousy when released in America 90 years ago, Varieté will be shown in New England in its complete, unexpurgated form for the very first time, in a gorgeous new digital restoration, with the 12-piece BSFO performing live-to-picture, conducted by the six student composers themselves.  

About the BSFO

​The recipient of a special commendation from the Boston Society of Film Critics, the Berklee Silent Film Orchestra (BSFO) is dedicated to composing new, original scores for silent feature classics, and performing them live-to-picture. Based at Boston’s Berklee College of Music, in the world’s only undergraduate degree program in film scoring, the student orchestra composes its new works, and performs as an ensemble, under the leadership of Professor of Film Scoring Sheldon Mirowitz (Outside Providence, Missing in America). To date, the BSFO has scored and performed nine iconic silent features including F.W. Murnau’s Sunrise, Faust, and The Last Laugh, Clarence Badger’s It, Sergei Eisenstein’s Battleship Potemkin, Buster Keaton’s Our Hospitality, E.A. Dupont’sPiccadilly, and Rupert Julian’s The Phantom of the Opera, each commissioned by the Coolidge Corner Theatre’s Sounds of Silents® program.

results.name: Varieté - and the Berklee Silent Film Orchestra world premiere Score

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
Do you want to deliver software projects faster and with greater efficiency? If so, you are not alone. However, many teams adopting a DevOps approach to software development are often tripped up by a variety of bottlenecks which prevent them from reaching maximum efficiency – ineffective collaboration, manual deployments, inconsistent environments, and slow hand-offs. Join us for an interactive discussion about DevOps approaches as we bring together experts from IBM, partners, customers and others sharing how to remove bottlenecks and deliver innovation continuously.


This discussion will cover: 


•  Building the business case for DevOps transformation including Hybrid Cloud •  Best practices to help those advance on their DevOps journey
•   Cultural challenges which can stifle an organization’s DevOps transformation
•   Choices cloud offers in a DevOps toolchain
•   Automating application deployment and release management
•   Real customer case studies, including people, process and product implications
•   Demos showing how to define, wire, and automate continuous application delivery

Register at the following URL:  http://ibm.biz/DevOpsBoston2
results.name: Cloud & DevOps Roundtable

results.description:
Join us to tap into your visual thinking skills and consider how they might impact your work and your company's culture!

During this session, consultant and arts educator Dabney Hailey will guide an open analysis of a work of art. You'll become part of an authentic learning culture under her expert stewardship, as we experience a discussion method called Visual Thinking Strategies (VTS). Rooted in research from cognitive psychology and arts education, VTS is currently used in business, healthcare, and education. What does VTS have to do with innovation in the workplace? To foster and sustain innovation, companies must cultivate growth mindsets, open communication and emergent leadership skills across team members. In other words, a healthy, productive workplace is one in which people are organized to learn and grow, not merely to execute. Visual Thinking Strategies models and teaches skills fundamental to teams that are structured to learn, break new ground, and achieve personal and organizational success.

Studies on VTS show that it:
-Enhances skills in observation, critical thinking, and collaboration
-Increases the value team members and leaders place on communication, and
-Develops comfort with ambiguity, which is key to preventing premature decisions in the face of complex problems.

Experience how developing visual thinking and facilitation skills can cultivate a healthy, productive discussion, within which everyone is accountable and focused, adaptable and creative, secure and open. ABOUT DABNEY HAILEY
Dabney Hailey is a management consultant, curator, and educator. She is a pioneer in implementing Visual Thinking Strategies as a leadership, team-building and problem-solving tool within businesses and nonprofits. She has lead VTS discussions and trained facilitators in a range of contexts (companies, large and small; museums; universities; and the medical world) since 2001. Her clients include major companies in financial services, retail, and IT as well as nonprofits and universities. Hailey is also an established curator, writer and educator specializing in modern and contemporary art.
results.name: CIC Arts Week Visual Thinking Strategies with Dabney Hailey

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
We will have two exciting quant finance talks on how to create a trend following fund by Saeed Amen and how unconventional data can generate alpha by Seong Lee. 

Stop by, meet other folks from our community, and have some pizza.

Agenda:

4:30-4:45: Welcome, network, & pizza

4:45-5:45: Saeed Amen will present How to build a CTA - Creating a trend following fund

5:45-6:00: Q&A

6pm-7pm Seong will present Think Breadth, Not Depth: How unconventional data generates alpha

How to build a CTA - Creating a trend following fund

In this talk we explain how to create trend following strategies which CTA-style funds typically follow. We shall also give a step by step demo of implementing an FX trend following strategy in PyThalesians (open source Python library for analysing markets)

Think Breadth, Not Depth: How unconventional data generates alpha

In recent years, the amount of data available to a quant has grown exponentially. Ease of technology and advancements in machine learning have made it possible for the retail quant to have access to data feeds like news & social media sentiment, crowd sourced earnings estimates, company fundamentals, and more. In this talk, Seong discusses how these data feeds could be the key to generating new sources of alpha along with specific, actionable steps to incorporate them into your practice.


Speaker Details:

Saeed Amen is managing director and co-founder of the Thalesians. He has a decade of experience creating and successfully running systematic trading models at Lehman Brothers and Nomura. Independently, he runs a systematic trading model with proprietary capital. He is the author of Trading Thalesians – What the ancient world can teach us about trading today (Palgrave Macmillan). He graduated with a first class honours master’s degree from Imperial College in Mathematics & Computer Science.


Seong Lee, is Quantopian’s Business Development lead. Seong holds a degree in computer science and finance from Boston College and has previously worked in big data building data analysis and monitoring systems prior to joining Quantopian in September of 2014.
results.name: Building a CTA & How Unconventional Data Generates Alpha

CALLING ALL New C&C Members!

                           Tonight is all about YOU

Bring your favorite game and show us how to play it or just come and meet some new people who share your same passion in game playing.

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford .  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play games.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start playing around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

O'Connors is open until 2am if you want to stay extra late, but they will open up the room to the public at 9:00pm.

results.description:
Hello Microservices enthusiasts,

We had fantastic turnout and response for our last event with Adrian Cockcroft. I have already uploaded the slides of that presentation to meetup and one of the attendees (Thanks Bryan) has also shared an audio recording for anyone interested.

Our next event is now scheduled on May 3rd. We have another great speaker with an interesting topic lined up. Since Pivotal labs did such a good job hosting us and taking care of us, we are going back to the same venue. I hope we will have same level of participation as our last event.

Details: 

Thanks to the Pivotal Labs team for offering to host our event at their office in Cambridge.

Meetup Agenda:

Introduction: Ajit Umrani, Assembla

Featured Guest Speaker:  Mark Richards, Independent Consultant and Author

Mark Richards is an experienced, hands-on software architect involved in the architecture, design, and implementation of microservices architectures, service-oriented architectures, and distributed systems in J2EE and other technologies. He founded the New England Java Users Group and served as president from 1999 through 2003. Mark is the author of numerous technical books and videos. He is a regular conference speaker at the No Fluff Just Stuff (NFJS) Symposium Series and has spoken at more than 100 conferences and user groups around the world on a variety of enterprise-related technical topics. You can read more about this background and publications here.


Topic - Microservices anti-patterns and pitfalls

Even though teams are gaining more experience in designing and developing microservices, nevertheless there is still a lot to learn about this highly distributed and somewhat complicated architecture style. Unfortunately, lots of microservices anti-patterns and pitfalls emerge during this learning curve. Learning about these anti-patterns and pitfalls early on can help you avoid costly mistakes during your development process. While anti-patterns are things that seem like a good idea at the time and turn out bad, pitfalls are those practices that are never a good idea at the time - ever. In this talk Mark will cover some of the more common pitfalls and anti-patterns you might encounter while creating microservices, and most importantly describe some of the ways of avoiding these pitfalls and anti-patterns.

Directions:

Address: Pivotal Labs, 145 Broadway, Cambridge MA 02142

It's at the corner of Broadway and Galileo Galilei Way. It's easily accessible by public transport. There is metered parking on broadway and a paid lot next door called "the blue garage". 

Other Announcements:

Best,

Please join us for 2 technical presentations with ample time to network and socialize with your peers.  The following presentations are as follows;

• Food and Beverages will be provided

Session 1

Speaker:  Actiance "Unleash Social Business" with Governance & Compliance

You will learn how to enable, meet and enforce current as well as future regulatory, legal, and corporate eDiscovery governance requirements by using today’s popular communications and social channels.

We will feature a presentation and technical discussion as well as

• Powerful granular policy control

• Content inspection

• Logging

• Real-time alerts

• Archiving for popular communications and social channels such as Skype for Business, SharePoint, public IM platforms, Presence, Yammer, Office 365, Facebook, and LinkedIn, among others.

Session 2   Customer Skype Testimonial

SPEAKER:  Steven K. Frederick, Information Technology Director at Moderna Therapeutics

Steven is accountable for the delivery of all IT capabilities and services for this rapidly growing Biotech.  Moderna is establishing a cutting-edge modality in scientific discovery by developing messenger RNA (mRNA) as a medicine.  Steven is leveraging creativity and innovation in the IT space to enable real-time collaboration, a cohesive set of productivity applications and flexible mobility tools, in a secure computing environment.  He effectively partners with all aspects of the business to design and deliver business solutions in a dynamic, growing Biotech start-up.

Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

https://youtu.be/OndSmceU9R4
results.how_to_find_us: Park in the unpaved municipal parking lot to the left of 72 Jefferson Street

Are you as excited about prose, poetry, screenplay writing, songwriting, and storytelling as we are? Eager to exercise your writing muscles?
Then join us for CIC Arts Week's Writing Workshop. Our workshops offer intriguing group prompts that are designed to be flexible enough for all writing styles. The focus of this month's workshop will be on incorporating natural and dramatic dialogue into our writing. Participants are not required to share their work; all we ask is that you arrive with an open mind and a willing pen (or computer)! Walk-ins welcome!

results.description:
Hello Hardwarians! 

We're back with another round of companies for you!

It's all about the teams, so each month we have 3 hardware startups present. They have time to pitch, take questions, and demo.  This month's meetup will be located at Bolt in Downtown Crossing.

Sponsor

This month we're sponsored by Wurth and Tektronix!

Tektronix: Headquartered in Beaverton, Oregon, Tektronix delivers innovative, precise and easy-to-operate test, measurement and monitoring solutions that solve problems, unlock insights and drive discovery. Tektronix has been at the forefront of the digital age for over 70 years. Join us on the journey of innovation at TEK.COM. Jeff Sable is the New England mainstream sales manager for Tektronix and Keithley products sold through distribution. [masked]


Wurth Electronics Midcom is a $12 Billion component manufacturer that specializes in EMI components such as ferrites, inductors, transformers, capacitors, shielding and interconnect products.  We offer direct support of small and midsize customers with free samples, design kits, software tools as well as engineering design support in an effort to help your product pass FCC class testing and UL certification. Wurth is one of the largest magnetics suppliers in the world with warehouse and production facilities all over the world.  We support you from prototype to production and never have minimum order quantities. We are also one of the leaders in the wireless power space with the largest selection of wireless power coils for the Qi standard.  Find out more at  www.we-online.com Jeff House is the regional manager for the Boston area and he can provide technical support, free design kits, as well as in-house seminars to train engineers on how to combat EMI issues and switching power supply design.  [masked]

Format

6.00P: Arrival, pizza, drinks

6.30P: A word from our sponsor: 

6.40P: Presentation #1: Accion Systems

6:55P: Presentation #2:  Hardware Startup Trends

7:10P: Presentation #3: Concrete Sensors

8.00P: Kick you all out

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Walkers & Joggers Welcome

May 3, 2016 @ 6:15PM (every Tuesday and Thursday night for 9 wks)

We're here to help you achieve your goal of beginning to run your first 5K. Too many people have been turned off of running simply by trying to start off too fast. Their bodies rebel, and they wind up miserable, wondering why anyone would possibly want to run in the first place. You should ease into your 5K training plan gradually. In fact, the beginners' program we outline here is less of a running regimen than a walking and jogging program. The idea is to transform you from couch potato to runner, getting you to begin running a 5K or 3.1 miles and on a regular basis in just two months.  Each session should take about 20 or 30 minutes, three times a week. That just happens to be the same amount of moderate exercise recommended by numerous studies for optimum fitness. This program will get you fit. 

We will be meeting twice a week, so you SHOULD train the 3rd time on your own either on Saturday or Sunday to keep with the schedule.  Remember to bring your sneakers and some water.
  http://www.coolrunning.com/engine/2/2_3/181.shtml


Inclement Weather: Heavy rains will cancel. We will train if it is overcast or there is a slight drizzle. Please plan to bring a lightweight jacket with a hood just in case.

results.name: Couch to 5K Training! (Walkers & Joggers Welcome!)

results.description:
Are you getting ready to raise seed investment for your company? Want to know what goes on behind the scenes when angel and seed investors contemplate whether or not to fund a venture? How do you create an investor-friendly financial model for your business?

On May 3rd, ENET will host a panel of leaders from the Boston seed and angel investing community who will answer your questions about how they make investment decisions. No presentations. No slides. At this meeting it will be just you, our panel of Angels, and your questions. As a founder, or founder-to-be this is your chance to ask the panel all those questions that are going through your mind about raising capital. Here are a few very common questions:


What are the best ways to find an angel who’s investment interests align with your objectives?

How do Angels pick investments? What criteria is most important to them?

How do Angels decide how to value my company and how much to invest?

As with every ENET meeting you will also get the chance to network with the panelists and other meeting attendees, both before the start of the meeting and afterwards. There will also be a pre-meeting dinner for additional networking.

Panel:

Deb Kemper, Managing Director, Boston Chapter of Golden Seeds, http://www.goldenseeds.com/ , Twitter: @Deb_Kemper


Deb Kemper is Managing Director of the Boston Forum of Golden Seeds, a national angel investor group. She is also a member of Clean Energy Venture Group. Her investment focus is high growth companies in the clean tech, health care, and technology sectors. Previously, Deb was a consultant with McKinsey & Company where she served clients in a variety of industries including energy, utilities, electronics, and healthcare. Her functional experience includes manufacturing, product development, operations, strategy, professional development, and leadership coaching.  She has provided leadership support to organizations in China, Peru and the United States. Deb earned her MBA from the Amos Tuck School at Dartmouth College where she was named an Edward Tuck Scholar. She holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil & Environmental Engineering from Cornell University where she graduated With Distinction and was a member of the Varsity Women’s Crew. She recently repatriated after living in Peru and China for 8 years. She resides in Boston with her husband and two children. Joseph W. Alsop, Venture Partner, Alsop Louie Partners, Co-Founder & former Chief Executive Officer Progress Software Corporation

JOSEPH ALSOP is a Venture Partner with Alsop Louie Partners, focusing on supporting early stage companies applying information technology in innovative ways. He was the co-founder and until 2009 the CEO of Progress Software Corporation, a global supplier of application infrastructure software used to develop, deploy, integrate and manage business applications. Joe led Progress from its founding to its position as a global software industry leader with annual revenue exceeding one half billion dollars. Alsop has over 25 years of management and technical experience in the computer industry.

Alsop received his B.S. degree in Electrical Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and attended the Sloan School of Management at MIT.


Michael R. Pratt, Managing Partner, Select Venture Partners, llc

Michael Pratt has over 40 years of experience in management and finance, in both domestic and international organizations, as well as more than two decades of involvement in the startup and venture capital industry. Michael’s experience includes early-stage company management, negotiation of strategic partnerships and alliances, and service on the Boards of Directors of several companies, including a public-traded corporation in New Zealand.

Michael is the Managing Partner of Select Venture Partners LLC, an early stage, post-seed/pre-Series A venture capital firm, with an experienced team, all of whom have extensive cross-industry and cross-functional operating experience in software startups. He is also Lecturer in Technology Entrepreneurship at the Clark School of Engineering at the University of Maryland, College Park.

Prior to Select, Mike co-founded and was CEO of SpydrSafe Mobile Security, Inc. SpydrSafe was acquired in February 2014. Prior to SpydrSafe, Michael was the COO of CardStar, Inc., a mobile loyalty company sold to Constant Contact (NASDAQ: CTCT). From 2006 to 2010, Michael was the CFO/COO of Trust Digital, Inc., a venture-backed Mobile Device Management company sold to McAfee (NYSE: MFE). Prior to Trust, Michael was CFO of Galt Associates, Inc., a venture-backed software company sold to Cerner Corporation (NASDAQ: CERN) in July 2006.  Earlier professional experience includes CEO of CrossMedia Networks Corp.; CEO of Point of Care Technologies sold to Siemens Healthcare in 1999 (ETR: SIE); various senior finance and operations positions with Mobil Corporation in both domestic and international settings, including President and General Manager of three Mobil subsidiaries. Michael began his professional career with Arthur Andersen & Co. Michael holds a BS in Finance from East Carolina University, a post-graduate degree in Business Administration from Massey University in New Zealand, and an MS, Marketing from The Johns Hopkins University.

Moderator:

Greg Dawe, https://www.linkedin.com/in/gregdawe, is ENET's Vice Chair of Operations and has been working in the software industry for over 30 years, first as an engineer, and later, in management. For over 10 years, Greg held senior management positions in the computer network security industry including experience with RSA Security, Inc. Greg specializes in establishing and growing new organizations directly linked to improving company results.
Greg Dawe @GlostaKenshi

E-Minute Presentations will be given at the start of the meeting. These very short presentations enable young startup entrepreneurs to gain experience in presenting their summary business plans to expert panels and audiences.

Directions: Constant Contact is adjacent to RT 128 / 95 at Exit 28B.

PRICE:

Non-ENET Member Rate – $20.00 

ENET Member Rate – Free 

MDG Member – $15.00 (USD)                                            

Student – $10.00 (USD)

TO REGISTER: http://www.boston-enet.org/event-2017602/Registration
results.name: Seed & Angel Financing

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.
results.name: Quite Write: Writing Night!

results.description:
We're a group of friendly folks who just love playing and getting together on a regular basis.  Our skills range from advanced beginner through experienced, and we're happy to help a 'newbie' or two learn the game.  Please bring a set if you have one; everyone will also need their own mah jong card.  Note that we will be playing American-style Mah jong, which is slightly different from Chinese mah jong.  American-style requires a mah jong card and uses jokers.  

We'd like to start the games at 6:30 promptly; feel free to come early and grab a bite from the Wegmans' cafe.  I'm typically upstairs around 6:00 to eat, meet, and greet!

Hope to see you on Tuesday nights!

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 6:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 6:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 9pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Tues May 3, 6:30-9pm)

Boston GBTP May – Remembering Barbara Anderson, other Taxing Problems… Common Core too

Most of you have probably heard about the passing of Barbara Anderson.

We will have an informal celebration of Barbara Anderson’s life, with CLT Founder Ed King.

We will also discuss the Graduated Income Tax and Common Core.  I hope to see you there.

Citizens for Limited Taxation will continue on. Please consider donating to CLT in her memory.

If people were able to view the movie Climate Hustle, we will have a discussion on that too.

I will include links below – a few to be aware of:

CLT Tribute Page –  http://www.cltg.org/cltg/clt2016/16-04-14.htm

CLT – Columns by Barbara Anderson​ –  http://cltg.org/cltg/barbara/

CLT – Her final column (a must read) –  http://cltg.org/cltg/barbara/2016/16-04-11_Fighting_pirates_with_the_Lost_Boys.htm

Barbara Anderson Remembered (GBTP) –  http://greaterbostonteaparty.com/?p=4283

----------------------------------------------

Traditional Boston Meeting notes:

We will again have a social hour at 6:30 pm and have the meeting begin at 7:30 pm.

Parking – from Parkopedia. It appears the Dalton Street garage is the best value, with a flat rate of $15 in the evening. Note the green lines denote on-street parking. You need to go to a meter pay station to get slip for your car – pay up to 8 pm.

Parkopedia:  http://en.parkopedia.com/parking/bar/lir-ma/

NOTE: As always with Boston parking, things are subject to change. Special events will cause parking lots to hike their prices, and we do not check in advance to see if there are any such occurrences coming up.

results.description:
Dick will demonstrate and explain why, and how easy to use and elegant FOSS and Linux have become, by using an inexpensive but powerful netbook computer, free software galore, and the power of open-source software that is created, improved, maintained, and inspected by thousands of motivated programmers and users without proprietary limitations.

A. Richard (Dick) Miller and Jill Miller are the partners of Miller Microcomputer Services (http://www.millermicro.com) in Natick, Massachusetts. Back when, they specialized in MMSFORTH. Once Linux became polished enough for regular use by regular clients, they migrated to that and other free, open-source software (FOSS) as their favored computing environment.

Dick and Jill also lead a regional FOSS User Group (http://NatickFOSS.org) in Natick, and they invite you to its free monthly FOSS and Linux extravaganzas. If you come to the Thursday May 5th NatickFOSS meeting with a USB thumb drive (with at least 8GB of free space), you can take home the weeks-old Ubuntu Linux 16.04 ready to test on your PC without installing; plus, you will learn various ways to install it alone or as an alternate "multi-boot" OS on your machine.

Note that we may videotape this meeting for later viewing and possibly broadcast.

We'll meet at Mass Bay Community College in Wellesley Hills.  As usual, admission is FREE and open to all.  Munchies and Intermingling (M&I) starts at 6:30pm, the meeting will start at 7pm and end by approximately 8:30pm. 

IMPORTANT: You need to have a (free) parking permit and directions.  These are located online (print yours) at http://www.bnug.org/parkingpermit
results.name: Free Open Source Software -- and Linux

results.description:
Welcome to the Cash Game Peregrine, where the blinds are .25/.50 and the game is dealer's choice or no limit holdem. There is no minimum buyin and the max is 200 bb ($100.) There is no rake, tipping, donation, or seat fee. House rules are posted below:

If it's your first time at one of my games RSVP on meetup then text, email, or call to confirm your RSVP and receive the address. If you RSVP and no-show without changing your RSVP, then you have likely taken a seat from someone else, made me very sad, and I put your name on the shit list. Don't do it. If you're running late I appreciate hearing from you.  Doors open at 6:35, and if you haven't arrived or contacted me about running late by 7:00, I will begin offering seats to the waitlist.  I reserve the right to cancel the game if we can't get enough players.

-1 chip=call

-Players must protect their hands at all times. If your hand is unintentionally mucked because you didn't protect it, there is no recourse, and the hand is dead. No exceptions.


-Verbally declared actions are binding. Tapping the table is considered a check. An unintentional action will be forgiven only once/night. Rules must be enforced fairly with all players, regardless of experience level. No exceptions.


-No string bets or splashed pots.

-Don't discuss hands as they are ongoing. Talking about hands or action is allowed only are when heads up, and only by the 2 players remaining in the pot.

-Hands must remain on table or not more than 12 inches from the edge of the table and must be visible to all players.

-Everyone makes mistakes but strive to pay attention so you act in turn in a timely fashion. If you have trouble knowing when it's your turn, let me know, and I'll help you with a reminder.


-If you are in a hand or on the button (dealing), you are not allowed to be on your phone. 

-Host's decisions on rulings are final.


-Once a player is done dealing, s/he must move the button to the next dealer.


-Cut-off shuffles, then passes the shuffled deck to the small blind to be ready for next deal.


-Rule violations that influence the course of a hand will be dealt with as follows: First time=warning, Second time=dealt out for next hand. Third time=dealt out for a round. Again, everyone makes mistakes, but an awareness of the game is important. If you have questions about proper poker etiquette, you are always welcome to ask.
results.name: .25/.50 Cash Game Peregrine (Tuesday)

We're inviting all single Boston  professionals ages 25-45 to join us a for a casual after-work networking social and speedmeeting social.

This gathering is for professionals who have completed or are currently pursuing an advanced or specialty degree i.e. Masters, MBA, PhD, Paralegal, JD, or other specialized certificate program.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

$20 - PREPAY ONLY

https://advanceddegreeboston.eventbrite.com

Schedule:

7pm -  Check in and mingle (Please try to check in by 7:30pm) Appetizers served from 7-7:30 or until gone.

7pm-8:00pm - Icebreaker & Mingle

8:00-8:30pm - A select amount of 3 minute speed rounds with other guests of the opposite sex.

8:30-9pm - More mingling

How it works:

-Arrive at the venue for socializing, cocktails and registration. You'll be given a name tag and your host will write your name and industry. You will also be given a sheet of paper that you can use to write down the names of people you met.

-Get your ice breaker piece to use for the mingling portion of  the happy hour.

-After the happy hour portion ends, you'll be seated and have a select amount of 3 minute "meet ups" with other guests.

-You'll turn in your sheet of paper where you've swritten down the names of people you wish to see again and you'll turn the sheet into the host. You will be able to choose betweem Friendship, Dating, and Professional (or all three!) as your preferred connection. If you have any mutual matches, we'll email you the email address of your matches within 48 hours.

ALL GUESTS ARE WELCOME TO EXCHANGE BUSINESS CARDS AND CONTACT INFO!

Can I come alone?  Yes, 98% of those attending will likely come on their own.

Dress code?  Be comfortable but keep it neat.

What is included?  $20 includes admission to the event,drink specials, and platters of appetizers served from 7-7:30pm or until gone.

results.description:
The illustrious infamous Explorers Club presents an: Exploration Talk by Michael Robinson. Who will take us on an illustrated journey with his recently released and thought-provoking book "THE LOST WHITE TRIBE: EXPLORERS, SCIENTISTS, AND THE THEORY THAT CHANGED A CONTINENT"

In 1876, the famed explorer Henry Morton Stanley encountered Africans with what he was convinced were light complexions and European features. Stanley's discovery of this African "white tribe" seemed to substantiate the so-called Hamitic Hypothesis: the theory that the descendants of Ham, the son of Noah, had populated Africa and other remote places, proving that the source and spread of human races around the world could be traced to and explained by a Biblical story.

In his book, Michael Robinson traces the rise and fall of the Hamitic Hypothesis. As Robinson shows, race theory stemming originally from the Bible not only guided exploration but archeology, literature, and also shaped the theories of Carl Jung who guided psychological and anthropological notions of the primitive. 

The Hypothesis also formed the foundation for the European colonial system, which was premised on assumptions about racial hierarchy, at the top of which were the white races, the purest and oldest of them all. It was a small step from the Hypothesis to theories of Aryan superiority, which served as the basis of the race laws in Nazi Germany. 

Based on painstaking archival research, The Lost White Tribe is a fascinating, immersive, and wide-ranging work of synthesis, revealing the roots of racial thinking and the legacies that continue to exert their influence to this day.


Michael Robinson is a professor of history at Hillyer College, University of Hartford. He studies exploration and its place within the cultural imagination. He also writes about the history of science and exploration on his blog "Time To Eat the Dogs". ___________________________________________________

The Social Hour begins at 7:00 p.m. in the hotel's (cash) bar and lounge above the second floor, and the PRESENTATION will begin at 8 p.m. 

Cost: to help defray the costs associated with room and equipment rental, the pith helmet will be passed around at the event for a requested $10 donation per person.

Parking: $10 in the Hotel Garage

For more info about the Explorers Club: www.Explorers.org
results.name: Race & Exploration Talk: "Lost White Tribe--the Theory that changed the World"

results.description:
This Meetup will be all the pieces of Thinking Into Results and I cannot wait to share it!

Take some time to answer these questions . . .

1. How frequently would you like to take a vacation if money wasn't a determining factor?

2. How much has your income increased, year by year, over the past 5 years?

3. What improvements would you like to see take place in your life over the next two years?

4. Describe a reoccurring concern or problem that you would like to eliminate: 

5. How much would you have to earn to eliminate all financial debt concerns in your life? 

6. How you would spend your day, every day, if you could truly do what you love to do?

7. What kind of a contribution do you dream of making to society?

8. If I could show you how to accomplish any of these, would you dedicate a specific period of time each day to make the changes necessary to accomplish the success you seek? 

The problem most of us face is that we have bought into the limiting beliefs that were handed to us and we have been living with them for so long we believe they are true.

This Quantum Leap workshop will show you how to answer these question so you can determine if you are ready to change.
results.name: Quantum Leaps in Your Life

results.description:
The illustrious infamous Explorers Club presents an: Exploration Talk by Michael Robinson. Who will take us on an illustrated journey with his recently released and thought-provoking book "THE LOST WHITE TRIBE: EXPLORERS, SCIENTISTS, AND THE THEORY THAT CHANGED A CONTINENT"

In 1876, the famed explorer Henry Morton Stanley encountered Africans with what he was convinced were light complexions and European features. Stanley's discovery of this African "white tribe" seemed to substantiate the so-called Hamitic Hypothesis: the theory that the descendants of Ham, the son of Noah, had populated Africa and other remote places, proving that the source and spread of human races around the world could be traced to and explained by a Biblical story.

In his book, Michael Robinson traces the rise and fall of the Hamitic Hypothesis. As Robinson shows, race theory stemming originally from the Bible not only guided exploration but archeology, literature, and also shaped the theories of Carl Jung who guided psychological and anthropological notions of the primitive. 

The Hypothesis also formed the foundation for the European colonial system, which was premised on assumptions about racial hierarchy, at the top of which were the white races, the purest and oldest of them all. It was a small step from the Hypothesis to theories of Aryan superiority, which served as the basis of the race laws in Nazi Germany. 

Based on painstaking archival research, The Lost White Tribe is a fascinating, immersive, and wide-ranging work of synthesis, revealing the roots of racial thinking and the legacies that continue to exert their influence to this day.


Michael Robinson is a professor of history at Hillyer College, University of Hartford. He studies exploration and its place within the cultural imagination. He also writes about the history of science and exploration on his blog "Time To Eat the Dogs". ___________________________________________________

The Social Hour begins at 7:00 p.m. in the hotel's (cash) bar and lounge above the second floor, and the PRESENTATION will begin at 8 p.m. 

Cost: to help defray the costs associated with room and equipment rental, the pith helmet will be passed around at the event for a requested $10 donation per person.

Parking: $10 in the Hotel Garage

For more info about the Explorers Club: www.Explorers.org
results.name: Race & Exploration Talk:"Lost White Tribe--the Theory that changed the World"

results.description:
Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.

results.description:
Lama Willa's teaching will explore the eight worldly winds, eight worldly preoccupations that interfere with full human flourishing. The fourth pair of these involve our attachment to gain and fear of loss. When this habitual pattern is recognized, we are freed up develop equanimity in the face of the ups and downs of this human life.  Join Lama Willa and the NDF Cambridge Sangha in person or via LiveStream (http://www.naturaldharma.org/live-teachings/) 

Willa B. Miller, PhD is the Founder and Spiritual Director of Natural Dharma Fellowship in Boston, MA and its retreat center Wonderwell Mountain Refuge in Springfield, NH. She is an authorized dharma teacher and lineage holder (lama) in the Kagyu lineage of Tibetan Buddhism, but practices in the Nyingma and Shangpa lineages as well. She is editor, author and translator (respectively) of three books: The Arts of Contemplative Care: Pioneering Voices in Buddhist Chaplaincy and Pastoral Work (2012), Everyday Dharma: Seven Weeks to Finding the Buddha in You (2009), and Essence of Ambrosia (2005). In 2013, she received a doctorate from Harvard University in Religion, and is currently Visiting Lecturer in Buddhist Ministry at Harvard Divinity School. Her academic teaching interests include Tantra and the Body, Buddhism and Ecology, and Buddhist Contemplative Care, among other topics. Outside of academia, her teaching specialties include the body as a door to awakening, natural meditation (mahamudra), and heart-cultivation (lojong). She is interested in the practical integration of meditation into daily life, and has participated as an advisor in several scientific studies on meditation. Her teachers and guides have included Kalu Rinpoche, Dilgo Khentse Rinpoche, Khenpo Tsultrim Gyamtso Rinpoche, Lama Norlha Rinpoche, and others. She currently derives inspiration for her practice and teaching from Lama John Makransky, Anam Thubten and Tsoknyi Rinpoche. She lives in Arlington, MA with her husband and two dogs, and frequently visits Wonderwell Mountain Refuge.

Please note: most of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending than are signed up using this web site.
results.name: The Eight Worldly Winds: Gain and Loss with Lama Willa Miller
