results.description:
This introduction is primarily intended to help newer members who have attended few PGN events to understand how to effectively start using PGN.  It is also useful for other members who would like a more formal introduction to PGN.

Topics

- What does "personal growth" mean?
- Why PGN is not for most people
  -- and are you one of the few who can benefit from it?
- How can you benefit from PGN?
- How can you best try out PGN?
- Critical navigation for PGN's site
- Problems some newbies have with PGN
-- and how to get around them

About the Personal Growth Network

The Personal Growth Network is a first-of-its-kind meta-organizer, bringing together diverse personal growth and positive psychology tools and techniques that are designed to help generally healthy people create greater joy and more success in all parts of their life.  Members can try out, learn, and practice numerous approaches; they can select some approaches for more in-depth study and application to their lives; they can practice, support, and share a particular approach with other members; and they can return to PGN to explore different approaches or to work on other parts of their life.  

PGN is also a community of like-hearted people who share an important, but not widely distributed, combination of values and characteristics (e.g., curiosity, willingness to learn, willingness to change habits) around consciously and proactively crafting a life well-lived.  For people with this important combination of characteristics, engaging with other members of the community can be fascinating, supportive, and affirming.

And finally, PGN is a toolbox with which members can create successful events.  Members can create workshops, practice groups, and social events through which they can share their journey, their gifts, their joy, their successes, their vision, and their interests.

About the Orientation Series

Given the enormous ambition and power of the Personal Growth Network, and its rapid growth, it is easy to feel a little overwhelmed at first, so we offer some "How-To" guides to maximize your utilization of the Personal Growth Network for whatever your goals may be.  


Our Orientations include:

For Participants 

- Thu Jun 16: Newbie Introduction 
. . . (For new, infrequent, or curious members) 


- Tues May 31: User's Guide 
. . . (For active members of PGN) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Thu Jul 28)

- Thu Jun 30: Advanced User's Guide 
. . . (For reducing emails and focusing on your growth areas) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Wed Sep 7)


For Leaders 

- Mon Aug 1: Intro to PGN Leadership 
. . . (For members considering offering events) 


- Sun May 8: Create an Event on PGN 
. . . (For members ready to offer an event) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Thu Sept 1)

- Sun May 15: Build Your Brand 
. . . (For leaders who want to build an identity.) 
. . . . . (Tentatively repeated on Thu Sept 29) 

For a list of all upcoming orientations:
- - > http://www.meetup.com/Personal-Growth-Network/messages/boards/thread/49755315/0/#[masked]

About This Particular Orientation:

There is no prerequisite to take this Orientation.  It is conceived of primarily for those members who are new to PGN, or have not tried out many events.  Some of the concepts introduced here are referred to in more advanced Orientations.

I will also try to address any specific questions that you post below. 

About The Technology:

This Orientation is offered as a "Zoom Webinar".  This means that you will need a computer, and you will need to be in a location where you can listen and watch without distractions.  (There will be opportunities for open discussion as well, so you may want to look presentable. )

The webinar software used is Zoom.  It runs on most platforms.  If you have not run it before, please click on the link a half-hour before to ensure that it is loads onto your system.

The link will be sent to you the day before the event.

Testimonials from Past Participants

I enjoyed the orientation, particularly making my way around the website and learning more about the PGN
- Marcos Palva

A comprehensive overview of all the possible ways to take advantage of this platform for personal growth. Very much similar to going through the buffet line.
- Phil Holberton

Lots of clear and useful information to make the most of PGN
- Andy Grant


Well done and looking forward to attending more events and meeting like minded people.
- Brian Shea

Informative and interesting. You did a nice job keeping our attention. I'm looking forward to being a part of PGN
- Deborah Helen

Very informative! Thanks! :)
- Ebony


The orientation was very helpful. I especially liked your warm, welcoming and lively facilitation
- Debbie
results.name: PGN_Orientation: The Newbie Introduction to PGN

results.description:
“Last Call” Screening on May 4, 2016, 7pm, in Concord MA (please note the prompt 7pm start time)

You are invited! To a screening of “Last Call.” In the early 1970’s, a team of scientists from MIT created the first computer model to analyze the interaction between exponential growth and finite natural resources on planet Earth.  Published as Limits to Growth, the work was promptly vilified throughout the 80’s and 90’s, primarily by economists and business interests.

In the 2000’s, independent researchers confirmed that data trends from[masked] have been following the Standard Run (business-as-usual) model scenario from Limits to Growth. The film Last Call tells us the story of Limits to Growth, and invites us to consider:  What happens next?

Prior to the film screening, our guest Dr. Kim Kastens will provide background on the development and testing of the Limits to Growth model.”   Dr. Kastens is a Special Research Scientist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University.

The following links may be helpful as reference if you wish:

• <a>http://www.lastcallthefilm.org/ </a>;

• https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Limits_to_Growth

• http://www.resilience.org/stories/2016-04-21/limits-to-growth-policies-to-steer-the-economy-away-from-disaster

• http://serc.carleton.edu/earthandmind/posts/last_call.html

• http://serc.carleton.edu/earthandmind/posts/deathrates.html

• http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2009/06/13/204231/robert-f-kennedy-gdp-obama-ponzi-scheme/

A discussion will follow the screening. 

General Information

Our First Wednesday Dialog series brings in outside speakers to share interesting topics related to Humanism -- kind of like Ted Talk. We socialize and enjoy refreshments until about 7:15, at which point the speakers presents for as long as they choose, usually until 8:00 or so. At this point we pass the mic around and have a group discussion about the topic. When the discussion wraps up, we continue with more refreshments and socializing until around 9:00 when all attendees are welcome to join our open steering committee meeting.

We  take donations at the door to cover the cost of the meeting ($5 is suggested). Half of the donations (after we pay the rent) are given as an honorarium to the speaker. All regular attendees are encouraged to bring refreshments to share.

Note that we have a large mailing list outside of Meetup.com so the RSVP numbers are generally much lower than the actual attendance.

results.name: First Wednesday Dialog - Film Screening of "Last Call"

This idea comes to us from Robin...

If you've lived in the area long, you probably have some story of either witnessing or being a part of a failure to share our public streets well, whether it was a driver, a cyclist or a pedestrian. How do we cooperate well in this aspect of urban life? 

Jacob was telling me about a Portlandia episode in which Max goes from advocating for bikers rights to drivers rights to walking rights, based on his transportation situation...How do we advocate for those whose interests differ from our own? How do we keep from having a migrating sense of justice based on our own social location?

results.description:
You are at the edge of the diving board. Do you jump or climb back down?

This life transformation healing is taking the jump from who

you are to who you want to be. Through our intention and the power of 

sound, we come together to stand in our power and resonate with the highest

versions of ourselves.  

As for the healing itself, everyone will lie down on comfy mats in a beautiful temple (bring your own blanket) and enter into a state of deep relaxation as I play my tibetan bowls and gongs and drum. As I go to do healing work with each one of you, everyone else benefits from the shifts that occur in more ways than one. 

I've done many healings before but this one is different.

As of now, I've stepped away from my job in the mundane word to do healing full 

time. When I first picked up a singing bowl over half a year ago, I did not 

know where  it was going to lead. But now I am happy to say it leads toward 

liberation.  I know all of you are on the same path of doing exactly what you want 

with your time. It is completely liberating when you follow your calling because 

your calling comes to you. All you need to do is answer. The universe supports us 

when we follow our bliss. 

I hope you can join me on the 6th ... If you want me to personalize your healing, 

beforehand call me at[masked]-8601. I make no claims for what I do. I merely 

facilitate and hold space for the healing and transformation you need to do 

yourself.  

An energetic contribution for this event keeps the cycle flowing!

Thanks and love,

Brian

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description:
Join us for a discussion and debate on beliefs! Base rules:

1. Be cool. Ad hominem attacks are not cool. If someone makes a point about your belief, saying they're just going to Hell anyway neither refutes their point nor adds to productive, friendly conversation.

2. Be open. Your positions will be put to the test against a devil's advocate. That should be okay with you.


3. Be respectful. It's like being cool. Everyone has a right to believe what they want, when you get right down to it.

4. Be honest. If someone makes a good point, don't dodge it.

5. Participate, if you're comfortable. There is no requirement to speak.

6. Burger for the banker? Running a meetup group does cost money, and while I don't expect it, I sure would shower anyone willing to kick me a few bucks and/or a food or beverage item with gratitude. :)


This session's topic: What is consciousness?

Where does it come from?

Is it more or less real than material reality?

What are your beliefs or non-beliefs regarding these ideas?

Share, listen, perhaps convince others of your position, and be open to expanding your ideas.


Location: Funky Murphy's

31 Main St, Marlborough, MA

Getting there: Find the VinBin on Google Maps (it's a good reference point). It's right next to a set of lights. You'll want to go straight through those lights, and then before the next set of lights, there's a plaza to your left. Funky Murphy's has a black sign and is a little hard to spot, so DM me if you have any trouble.

I look forward to another great discussion!


- R. Miles
results.how_to_find_us: Coming from 495: Get off at 24A and continue following route 20. The library will be on your left at a set of lights. Keep going down Main Street through the center of town. Funky Murphy's is in a plaza with a black sign.

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.
results.name: Dance Freedom Dj's Robin & Alan S. Facilitator David Kahn

results.description:
Pandemic is a board game where the players cooperate to try to save the world from an outbreak of disease. It's a lot of fun in its own right, involving planning and strategy balancing conflicting aims.

The biased part is a twist we add to it. Each person picks a cognitive bias to role-play and then chooses their move accordingly. For example, they might try to address a minor immediate threat instead of a critical future threat. The only way they can go back on their proposed bad move is if the other players can describe the general flaw in their reasoning. So we practice recognizing different kinds of flawed reasoning while playing a fun board game.


Our schedule is as follows:

• 7:30 Arrival and introductions

• 8pm Game begins

• 11pm End

Attendees are welcome to bring snacks, drinks, or game recommendations.
results.name: Wednesday Game Night: Biased Pandemic

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:


Organizer/Event Host:
Jenna  (SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor:
Wendel C.

Sponsored by:
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location:
Abington

Cost:
$15.00 with Kangoo rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.


Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick high socks, similar to those you would wear with roller blades or ski boots (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP:
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.


Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:

- We meet in the Zass Zumba Studio

- Don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

- Don't eat a full meal up to an hour before class.

- Open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

- Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite 

- Bring a snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

Future Kangoo Jump Events:
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 

Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.
results.name: Kangoo Jumps Workout

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
This presentation will cover deep dive into fault tolerant HDFS file operators, and extending Yahoo! streaming benchmarks to Apache Apex the next generation native Hadoop platform that does both streaming and batch. Apex is commonly used for big data ingestions and transformations.

Agenda:

9:15pm: Deep dive into how operators read from and write to files for exactly-once semantics - Chandni Singh, committer Apache Apex 

10:00pm: Q&A 

10:15pm: Extending Yahoo Streaming computation Benchmark to Apache Apex - Sandesh Hegde, committer Apache Apex 

Abstract: 

Talk #1: Deep dive into how operators reads and writes from/to files in an idempotent manner. This will cover file input operator, file splitter, block reader on the input side and file output operator on the output side. We will present how these operators are made scalable and fault tolerant with the hooks provided by Apache Apex platform. 

Talks #2: Extending Yahoo Streaming computation Benchmark to Apache Apex 

- Application topology 

- Comparison of results between Storm, Flink and Apex 

- Variation of the Apex Benchmarking App with event time and 'results query' support 

- Demo 

Please register for Fault Tolerant HDFS r/w with Apache Apex; and Apex (native Hadoop) benchmarks on May 4, 2016 at: https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/8175875379681147652

After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the webinar.

@ApacheApex, meetup presentations, meetup recordings, download, Apache Apex releases, docs

This webcast is of an Hadoop Ingest and Transform meetup event in another city (2833 Junction Ave, #200, San Jose, CA), we are webcasting it enable other Big Data Ingesters to participate. If you are interested in helping organize (hosting, presenting, community leadership) Hadoop Ingest & Transform community, please email [masked]

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Come check out HyperLedger Boston's first meetup! They'll be talking basics of open blockchain technology and hosting a discussion comparing the Ethereum and Hyperledger protocols. Eventbrite here https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hyperledger-boston-meetup-registration-24484952151 

Please NOTE: Your presence on the waitlist on meetup.com does not mean that you will not be credited to the list of attendees. If you are registered at EVENTBRITE.COM (just you First and Last name (as on your ID), company and email), and are on a waitlist on meetup, you will be 100% allowed! Agenda:


5:30 - Doors open. Networking. 6:15 - Welcome. Members to vote on the topics of interests for the future meetings. 6:45 - 7:45 Technical Introduction to Open Blockchain (OBC) 7:45 - 8:30 Hyperledger vs Ethereum - A War in the Making, or a Match Made in Heaven?" 8:30 - Hyperledger: Project update. Next steps. 9:00 - Wrap-up. DETAILED AGENDA:

6:45 - 7:45 Technical Introduction to Open Blockchain (OBC) Would you like to understand how the Open Blockchain (OBC) works, exactly? The IBM Open Blockchain (OBC) project is IBM's contribution to the Linux Foundation Hyperledger project. IBM made it available as open source to enable the community to explore our architecture and design.

In this presentation, the enthusiasts of Open Blockchain at Altoros will share their hands-on experience tinkering with the magic of the Open Blockchain project and its chaincode.

Part 1. Open Blockchain Protocol

Part 2. Chaincode

Part 3. Open Blockchain API

Part 4. Consensus algorithm

Part 5. Putting this all to work. How about writing our first app!?

7:45 - 8:30 Hyperledger vs Ethereum - A War in the Making, or a Match Made in Heaven?"

Panelists: - Ed Featherston is a senior level Enterprise/Systems/Application Architect @ Collaborative Consulting with 34+ years of strong information technology experience, possessing technical expertise in systems integration, Internet/Intranet, client/server, middleware, and cloud technologies. Ed has designed and delivered numerous Internet and Intranet projects for a variety of industries, including financial services, government, pharmacy and retail.

- Gari Singh, Distinguished Engineer, Blockchain @ IBM Middleware
Gari is a Versatile technologist with over 16 years of experience in end-to-end product delivery, including 5+ years of product management, 9+ years of sales and technical sales and 7+ years of consulting and implementation.

8:30 - Hyperledger: Project update. Next steps.

Updates on the project from IBM perspective by Gari Singh @ IBM

9:00 Wrap-up. Please NOTE: Your presence on the waitlist on meetup.com does not mean that you will not be credited to the list of attendees. If you are registered at EVENTBRITE.COM (just you First and Last name (as on your ID), company and email), and are on a waitlist on meetup, you will be 100% allowed!
results.name: HyperLedger vs. Ethereum

results.description:
Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Marlborough Couch to 5K sponsored by ConnectingPoint Church. We love people in our community. We've helped over 400 people get off the couch and start jogging!


We have 2 groups: 

 1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K. 

 2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us. 

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Sprit of Hudson 5K in June 

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group. 

Please arrive 15 minutes early the first night, so we can explain what you'll be doing on the Rail Trail, stretching out, etc.


 Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising. 

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

https://youtu.be/OndSmceU9R4
results.how_to_find_us: Park in the unpaved municipal parking lot to the left of 72 Jefferson Street

results.description:
Register before Sunday to save $10 on your ticket!

Women need to take ownership today if we are going to lead a fair, inclusive industry with global reach and trillion-dollar potential. Join Women Grow: Boston to learn about current job paths and opportunities in the cannabis industry, and how you can transfer your skills into the first billion-dollar industry not dominated by men.

Shaleen Title, Esq., Co-Founder of the premiere national cannabis industry staffing firm, THC Staffing, and Cara Crabb-Burnham, Dean of Faculty at Northeastern Institute of Cannabis and former President of the Massachusetts Cannabis Reform Coalition, will present at this interactive and enlightening event that will help guests dive into the industry with confidence and clarity.

AGENDA

6:00 - 6:30 -- Registration and networking

6:30 - 7:45 -- Panel discussion and audience Q&A

7:45 - 8:30 -- Open networking

Women Grow Networking Events connect aspiring and current professionals in the cannabis industry. Through our monthly events, our members develop authentic relationships via personal contact and networking. While our events are women focused, our networking series attracts both men and women to connect.

Click here to register. 

SPEAKERS

Shaleen Title, Esq.</a> has more than ten years of experience helping people start careers in marijuana policy and business. She is frequently quoted in industry and news publications, and has won several awards for her advocacy work and her efforts to bring more women and people of color into drug policy reform.

As an attorney specializing in marijuana regulations, she has provided regulatory expertise for leading marijuana consulting firms including 4Front Advisors and Vicente Sederberg. In 2012, she helped make history by serving as a senior staffer for Amendment 64, Colorado’s historic initiative that made Colorado the first state in the U.S. to legalize marijuana. She led the creation of professional coalitions, including academic endorsements from hundreds of university professors, and recruited teams of volunteers to represent the campaign throughout the state.

She helped create and fund the Students for Sensible Drug Policy Diversity Scholarship, which seeks to widen the perspectives and backgrounds of people joining the drug policy movement. She has served on the board of national organizations including Students for Sensible Drug Policy and the National Lawyers Guild, and she currently serves as board member for Marijuana Majority, Family Law & Cannabis Alliance, and the Minority Cannabis Business Association. As the Speakers Bureau Director for Law Enforcement Against Prohibition, Shaleen recruited high-profile judges, law enforcement officers, DEA agents and prosecutors to speak out in favor of legalization. She placed an emphasis on diversity, more than doubling the number of women representatives during her time at LEAP.

<a href="https://instituteofcannabis.com/about/staff/cara-crabb-burnham/">Cara Crabb-Burnham</a> is the Dean of Faculty at Northeastern Institute of Cannabis and a former the President of the Massachusetts Cannabis Reform Coalition (MassCANN). As a director with MassCANN for four years, she was aspeaker and volunteer coordinator for the Boston Freedom Rally, organized several events and raised thousands of dollars to put toward cannabis policy reform in Massachusetts. She has traveled across the country attending cannabis events and speaking on behalf of Massachusetts and the national shift in opinion. As a co-host of the Boston Pot Report, previously on UNregular Radio and returning on WEMF Radio, she has interviewed some of the most influential people in the cannabis community including Lester Grinspoon, Diane Fornbacher, and Diane Russell.

She began her career in cannabis through Students for Sensible Drug Policy at Emerson College, assisting in the founding of that chapter. She worked with chapters throughout Boston and New England to help promote student issues with drug use. Cara helped found the NORML Women’s Alliance with representative from three New England states. She was the first in the New England drug policy community to work alongside the gay rights movement; she walked with SSDP in the Boston Pride Parade for two years before the NWANE group donated space to have a table at the Boston Pride Festival at Government Center. She has been recognized by both High Times and SKUNK Magazines.

Through NIC she has developed curriculum, operations policies, and a variety of other seminars and events on campus. 

F.A.Q.

Why should I consider a career in the cannabis industry? Watch our videos on <a href="https://vimeo.com/105057015">getting started in the cannabis industry and why women should get involved.

Who attends Women Grow events? You'll meet women (and men) at all different stages of their career in the cannabis industry. Many will be in the research phase, just learning more about opportunities, while still working day jobs. Some are looking for jobs with existing organizations. Others are starting up their own cannabis venture or ancillary business. Depending on the status of legalization in your state, you'll also meet cannabis business owners & investors who are well on their way. <a>Watch the video</a> to see for yourself.

Why attend? Personal connections are the key to professional success. Through the wide variety of events offered to members of Women Grow, trustworthy business relationships sprout from the face-to-face interactions of our members. Together we have more power. As the cannabis industry grows on a national and global scale, women have the opportunity to build a new American industry from inception and redefine the workplace to create environments in which we can flourish and define our own destiny, and cultivate the next generation of industry leaders.

Contact [masked] with additional questions about our events, sponsorship opportunities and membership.

results.description:
Join us for a fun, stimulating evening of group critique and discussion.

New members are always welcome. We'll be prepared to discuss work in any genre, prose or verse. Bring enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss for each workshop attendee to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! We are similarly open to suggestions for writing exercises, discussions at members' homes, visits to readings or bookstores, and other events of interest to writers.

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: Now in its 14th year, the weekly Boston Poetry workshop (formerly “Charles River Writers”) is an open, accessible, and welcoming forum for literary fellowship and discussion. Please note: In 2016, our Thursday night workshops will run in six-week blocks, in winter, spring, summer, and fall.

Come paddle at one of our practice sessions with Living Root, your 2015 Boston Dragon Boat Festival Grand Champions! We're a social and friendly co-ed team who enjoy the sport of dragon boat paddling. 

Are you new to paddling? No problem! We'll show you everything you need to know to paddle on a dragon boat. This is a great way to meet people, get in shape, and do something fun in the sun.

We meet at 6pm at the docks behind the Barking Crab (88 Sleeper Street in Boston), a short walk from South Station.  We paddle rain or shine, so dress for the weather.  Wear comfortable workout clothing and footwear that you don't mind getting wet. Bring a bottle of water, and we'll provide all the paddling equipment you'll need and a place to lock up your belongings.  We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice. So come join us!  Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked]. 

Additional Location and Parking information can be found here

Check out our website or find us on Facebook!

results.description:
We look forward to seeing everyone tomorrow night for this event!

To attend: You must RSVP via GA's link below in order to attend this event:  https://generalassemb.ly/education/digital-rendezvous/boston/23170

Digital Rendezvous at General Assembly 

The next Digital Rendezvous will focus on Front End Development, with a panel of Sr. Front End Developers who will discuss their experience in the field and upcoming trends. This will also be an opportunity for Developers, especially those currently enrolled in the General Assembly Program, to network with working Development professionals and Vitamin T recruiters.

What: Digital Rendezvous with developer panel

Where: General Assembly
51 Melcher St, Boston, MA 02210

When: May 5th.
6:00-7:00p - Networking
The discussion will begin promptly at 7:00p.

•Important: You must RSVP via GA's link below in order to attend this event. RSVP link: https://generalassemb.ly/education/digital-rendezvous/boston/23170

OUR SPEAKERS:

Scott Cobban (Moderator)


Scott is a highly motivated software engineer, who flourishes in a fast-paced, creative environment. He is able to manage multiple development aspects of a project from concept to completion; he excels at finding creative solutions to complex problems. He has been in the web space since 2000 and is now the Sr. Front End Developer at Scout Exchange. Scott has an energetic personality and even sings in an a cappella group!


PANEL:  

Bjorn 
Bjørn is the Manager of Front End Development at Motus, where he does anything and everything related to the internet. With a background in graphic design and web development, his current focus is on deepening and enriching the company’s unique brand persona across all channels, and experimenting with innovative technologies. In his free time Bjørn fixes old motorcycles and takes on woodworking projects.


Chris 
Chris is an ultra-rare sr. Developer and Web Consultant that speaks in plain English so everyone can understand. Christopher allows people to focus on accomplishing the mission at hand. In addition, he just happens to be a multiple award-winning Website Developer with 12 years worth of wide ranging and proven expertise. He is well known for his dedication and exceeding client expectations. He has been on some great email projects lately and can help out!


Raphael 
Raphael is a passionate, curious learner who learned the trade while running a small family business in Winchester, MA. He's since moved to Worcester with his wife and daughter and commutes to Boston. Raphael developed an app to automate the rug cleaning industry's invoice management, scheduling, inventory and business communications. Raphael specializes in the MEAN & LAMP stacks, cloud technologies, server management and loves JavaScript & CSS. Readability and maintainability is at the heart of his work.


Zak 
Meet Zak! He is an Interaction Designer who has a background in front end development, graphic design, and UI/UX. He has done work for clients including WIN Interactive, Sensory Interactive, Blue Whale Studios, and more. Zak’s experience includes interaction design/visual design (web banners, technical illustrations, web content, etc.), front end development (all desktop, no mobile), and UX/UI design (interactive and touch table UI, live event experience, animated training tools, etc.) His front end skills include HTML, CSS, and light JavaScript (mainly Java). He can recognize what does what and make any tweaks/changes and can optimize/test code. He spent the last year and a half doing an accelerated front end development role at WIN Interactive - they pushed out a software package / suite of applications in just under 11 months.

results.description:
Welcome to the Cash Game Summit, where the blinds are .25/.50 and the game is dealer's choice or no limit holdem. There is no minimum buyin and the max is 400 bb ($200.) There is no rake, tipping, donation, or seat fee. House rules are posted below:

If it's your first time at one of my games RSVP on meetup then text, email, or call to confirm your RSVP and receive the address. If you RSVP and no-show without changing your RSVP, then you have likely taken a seat from someone else, made me very sad, and I put your name on the shit list. Don't do it. If you're running late I appreciate hearing from you. Doors open at 6:35, and if you haven't arrived or contacted me about running late by 7:00, I will begin offering seats to the waitlist. I reserve the right to cancel the game if we can't get enough players.


-1 chip=call

-Players must protect their hands at all times. If your hand is unintentionally mucked because you didn't protect it, there is no recourse, and the hand is dead. No exceptions.

-Verbally declared actions are binding. Tapping the table is considered a check. An unintentional action will be forgiven only once/night. Rules must be enforced fairly with all players, regardless of experience level. No exceptions.

-No string bets or splashed pots.

-Don't discuss hands as they are ongoing. Talking about hands or action is allowed only are when heads up, and only by the 2 players remaining in the pot.

-Hands must remain on table or not more than 12 inches from the edge of the table and must be visible to all players.

-Everyone makes mistakes but strive to pay attention so you act in turn in a timely fashion. If you have trouble knowing when it's your turn, let me know, and I'll help you with a reminder.

-If you are in a hand or on the button (dealing), you are not allowed to be on your phone. -Host's decisions on rulings are final.

-Once a player is done dealing, s/he must move the button to the next dealer.

-Cut-off shuffles, then passes the shuffled deck to the small blind to be ready for next deal.

-Rule violations that influence the course of a hand will be dealt with as follows: First time=warning, Second time=dealt out for next hand. Third time=dealt out for a round. Again, everyone makes mistakes, but an awareness of the game is important. If you have questions about proper poker etiquette, you are always welcome to ask.
results.name: Cash Game Summit (Thursday)

Add cloud functionality to your mobile app! Join Gavin Bauman, Microsoft Technical Evangelist, as he details how to use Azure App Service: Mobile Apps as the backend for your mobile app. He’ll cover creating a mobile backend, adding in support for push notifications, and using current industry standard user authentication providers

Speaker:
Gavin Bauman graduated from Xavier University of Louisiana (class of 2014) with a Bachelor’s degree in Computer Science. Upon graduation, he joined Microsoft as a Technical Evangelist in the Boston area. He’s given numerous technical and professional development talks, speaking at local events such as Boston Code Camp as well as national events like PAX East. Gavin has also worked with numerous schools, meetup groups, and independent professionals in the community. When he’s not punishing his foes in the online games he prefers, he’s focusing on leveraging the Azure cloud platform to develop mobile apps and media solutions.

results.description:
The Man Who Knew Infinity (film)

"What does it take to prove the impossible?"



"Based on the untold story of one of the greatest minds of his generation, The Man Who Knew Infinity charts the incredible life of Srinivasa Ramanujan (Dev Patel, Slumdog Millionaire), whose genius for mathematics takes him from the slums of India to Trinity College, Cambridge University in the early 20th-century. Spurred on by his mentor G. H. Hardy (Academy Award winner Jeremy Irons, Reversal of Fortune), Ramanujan overcomes racism and the rigidity of academia to revolutionize the field with his startlingly original theorems, which he attributes to divine inspiration. Driven by the engaging rapport between Patel and Irons as two vastly different men who find common ground in the world of numbers, The Man Who Knew Infinity is a fascinating look at how an unlikely, cross-cultural friendship changed the world."


Movie Details at Kendall SQ web site

Check out the trailer:

https://youtu.be/Jji1zSwxstU
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the front of the lobby, right side.  Showtime is 7:05PM
results.name: What does it take to prove the impossible?

Every Thursday evening at 6:30 PM we gather as a group for a nice nighttime "romp" at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. It's a great way to wind down a busy work day, to catch up with Bulldogs friends, or to meet new people!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there! 

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]

results.description:
If you are newly alone and trying to cope - by yourself - with the emotions of loss or grief, then New Beginnings Wellesley Hills could be for you. You will be with people who are, or have been, in the same boat as you. You may be having feelings such as anger, denial, shock, depression, loneliness, rejection, or abandonment these all are normal for where you are. You will be able to share how you feel in a safe place, and get support and comfort from others who have been there.

Our weekly meetings combine group membership activities with small group discussions led by trained facilitators. Our typical meeting schedule is as follows:

6:30 to 6:45 PM – Orientation for visitors & new members
6:30 to 7:00 PM – Social time & refreshments
7:00 to 7:55 PM – Program / Group activity / Speaker (Check out our website for more information)
7:55 to 8:00 PM – Opening Circle / Visitor Welcome / Announcements
8:00 to 9:00 PM – Support Time / Small Group format

For additional information please visit our website at www.newbeginningswellesley.org or contact us at [masked]

results.description:
Anger is a normal, healthy emotion. When it is expressed appropriately, it can become a helpful force that enables you to take action and communicate in an assertive manner. When expressed with blame and aggression, towards yourself or others, it can be a destructive force. It can lead to a variety of health and behavioral consequences.


We can all benefit from developing some mastery over our anger. The Anger Mastery Group can help you learn the skills you need to turn your anger into a positive force. We will meet weekly, in a supportive group environment, where you can share your experiences with others.

The group starts on May 5th and will run for 5 weeks. The cost is $20 per session. Please pre-register here to attend: http://www.whole-living-center.com/anger/

The group is led by Damon Pryor: 

http://www.whole-living-center.com/damon/
results.name: Anger Mastery Group - 5 Weekly Sessions.

results.description:
I will present these slides covering the fundamentals of Transaction-Level Verilog (version 1c), including online lab exercises (which require laptop and Google or Facebook acct.).  Interested lab participants can stay to work through this tutorial series with guidance.

TL-Verilog simplifies RTL design, whether you are a novice or a seasoned veteran.  If you code RTL for a living, learn how to finish a day's work and be home before 5pm.  If you are learning a new skill, there's no better way to get started.

A basic understanding of digital logic and RTL is the only prerequisit. While I could never teach Verilog in a single evening, coding in TL-Verilog is simpler, yet more powerful.  You'll leave with everything you need to write TL-Verilog models of your own.  TL-Verilog designs are half the size of their Verilog/SystemVerilog counterparts, and easier to manipulate.

results.description:
Abstract:
Openshift has the mechanism for building and deploying applications and Jenkins is a tool use for continuous integration/delivery/deployment. If we combine these together we can create a CI/CD pipeline that will allow us to test applications in Jenkins from github or a docker registry, promote and build them in Openshift and then deploy them to different projects in Openshift.

Speaker Bio
Ari is a Principal Software Engineer at Red Hat. He has been working with continuous integration/delivery/deployment workflows for the past six years at both Red Hat and VMware. His main focus at Red Hat now is with the team that delivers Project Atomic and Openshift Enterprise solutions for Red Hat. He has developed several tools that help to provision and configure resources in different environments, such as OpenStack, Beaker, AWS, and Docker. He is also a contributor to Jenkins Job Builder a tool to easily manage and maintain Jenkins Jobs in a simple YAML format. http://docs.openstack.org/infra/jenkins-job-builder/
results.name: Talks with Ari LiVigni and Jenkins Founder Kohsuke Kowaguchi

results.description:
Two PyCon-bound speakers will rehearse their talks, sponsored by Better Outcomes.


Geoff Gerrietts: Diving into the Wreck: a Postmortem Look at Real-World Performance

As a young engineer interested in performance, much of the advice I saw on performance management focused on algorithms and rules of thumb. It’s good advice, but it doesn’t address the most common problems. This talk will cover a handful of the most common performance problems I’ve encountered in my career. We will talk about how to recognize them, what causes them, and how to resolve them. More info...


Ned Batchelder: Machete-mode Debugging: Hacking Your Way Out of a Tight Spot

When chasing mysterious bugs, it's helpful to use all the tools at your disposal. We'll explore ways to use Python's dynamic tools to help track down the cause of head-scratching problems in large systems. Tools include the inspect module, monkey-patching, trace functions, and the Python mechanisms at work behind them all. More info...

Pizza will be provided.

Because these are rehearsals, we will not be recording.  You'll be able to see the recording from the actual presentation given at PyCon.
results.name: PyCon Rehearsals 2: Performance Post-Mortem, and Machete Debugging

results.description:
Crossroads Irish Pub (Boston,  Beacon St and Mass Ave intersection) 7 pm to 10 pm

Due to requests and great turnout, Japanese Evening Table is going back to Crossroads! Grab a few drinks and some delicious cheap bar food. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking in the area is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. Also, watch out for those hidden street cleaning signs! If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway to Hynes or bus #1 to stop between Beacon and Marlborough.

Ordering at Crossroads: 

1) Order all your drinks and food at the bar. 

2) Start a tab (付け) or pay as you go. Don't forget to tip. 

See you there!


~Lindsay
results.how_to_find_us: Probably on the first floor, but send a message if you can't find us!
results.name: Backbay Japanese Evening Table

results.description:
Great Boston NLP & Hypnosis Meetup - Lexington

Topic: The Law of Life is Our Belief

This will be an exciting night.  My good friend Erin Plunkett will be leading the hypnosis sessions tonight.  She has a wealth of knowledge in many areas of complementary healing.  She has recently developed some hypnosis scripts which she will deliver.

Tonight, let’s explore some of the Beliefs that are in our lives that hamper us in creating what we say we want to have in this World:  Our Dreams: …… the “Perfect Job we love”…… the “Perfect Partner who is our Best Friend”……

the “Perfect Dream Home”….. “Perfect Health”……. the “Perfect Life we envisioned”…..      you get the picture!

We will hold the conversation to explore the various places where these Beliefs “we hold true” may have come from in our lives…… some of which may even surprise you when you come to learn that we are unable to completely “blame our parent figures”!

We will explore:  


   - What has been done in the past by you to shift these Beliefs? 

   - What has worked in this process? 

   - And what has not worked for you…….

Then as a group, we will have the experience to shift some of these Limiting Beliefs that have been “held to be true”.  This will be done during a group Hypnosis session that is being conducted by the most Reverend Erin-Dail Plunkett. 

She will be leading us down the Path to:  True Wealth and Prosperity.

The Most Reverend Erin-Dail Plunkett was recently certified as a Clinical Hypnotherapist.  She has added this specific skill to her Tool Box, which also includes Reiki, Coaching, Dowsing and Feng Shui in her new business, soon to be debuting.  Reverend Erin’s journey to Hypnosis began +7 years ago, first as a client who wanted to shift the behavior of smoking to that of a non-smoker.  As Reverend Erin’s studies evolved, she grew to feel that the Human Being’s subconscious mind is an integral part of the Energy work that she also engages in within her clients….. “Our thoughts are the Energy and that with which we create our internal and external experiences of the world in which we participate in daily.”  With this philosophy in mind, Reverend Erin’s mission is to help in transforming the lives of others; and to assist them in creating their Highest Version of themselves so that they may experience a Joyful and Prosperous Life.  Reverend Erin does this by helping her clients to transition beyond their own Limiting Beliefs utilizing the practices and teachings of Holistic Wellness and Esoteric Wisdom that has been handed down through the ages.


Come and Have Fun.

Kevin Martin, CHT

www.poseffects.com

We're also quite eager, you know, to share an amazing May sponsor: Eager.io!


---

Building Minesweeper - without frameworks  w/ Sarah Frisk
github: https://github.com/sfrisk
twitter: https://twitter.com/sarahfrisk
website: http://www.sarahfrisk.net

Minesweeper: the epic puzzle game of numbers that led to hours of homework procrastination throughout the 90s and 2000s.  Perfect introduction for learning the basics of game development in JavaScript, this exploration into JavaScript via the Canvas element will look at developing games without the use of a JavaScript library or framework

Sarah is a senior software developer for Vet’s First Choice in Portland Maine, Project Lead for the jQuery Foundation’s Chassis project, an indie game dev enthusiast, and a webcomic creator.

---

From idea to proposal to JavaScript Feature w/ Leo Balter
github: https://github.com/leobalter
twitter: https://twitter.com/leobalter

It's known JavaScript is implemented following a standard specification, currently the ES2015 or just ES6. It's also known it is a work in progress with the upcoming ES2016 and ES2017. TC39, the current group moving ECMAScript forward, has a detailed staging process, which will be explained on a way to understand how an idea becomes reality featured in the specs and implemented in the browsers. 

---

From Will's description of previous events:

We usually end up sitting in left-middle section of the balcony, since this affords a good view of the entire orchestra, is open to the ceiling, and is easy to describe and find, and it is relatively easy to grab a large block of seats there.

From Kirk: If the balcony is not open(*****It is unlikely that the balcony will be open, based on recent concerts.*****), we'll try to sit in the middle section, towards the back. 

Directions to Jordan Hall: 
The hall is located at the corner of Huntington and Gainsborough streets, about a block south of the Symphony T stop on the Green Line. Look for the building with the YMCA sign on top of it--it's near that building. The main entrance is reached from Gainsborough Street.

Price: Free 

Location: NEC's Jordan Hall

From NEC:

Great artists give free concerts at New England Conservatory—simply because they teach here.

Piano faculty member Alexander Korsantia has won great critical acclaim for his versatility, power and the unique sincerity of his playing. He can be heard performing in many of the world's foremost concert halls collaborating with renowned artists such as Valery Gergiev, Christoph Eschenbach, Paavo Jarvi, Gianandrea Noseda, Yuri Bashmet, Yuri Temirkanov, Vadim Repin, the Jerusalem Quartet and Sakari Oramo, among others.

Here he presents a program of Haydn, Beethoven, Ravel and Copland.

Program

Copland: Variations for Piano

Beethoven: Six Variations on a Theme in F Major, Op. 34

Beethoven: Variations (15) and Fugue for Piano in E flat major, Op. 35 "Eroica"

Haydn: Piano Sonata in E-flat major. Hob. XVI\49

Ravel: La valse

Date: May 5, 2016 - 7:30PM

Price: Free

Location: NEC's Jordan Hall

NEC's FREE concerts do not require a ticket, unless stated in concert listing. Unreserved seating is available on a first-come, first-served basis. Doors open 30 minutes prior to the concert's start time.

results.description:
Join us to eat, drink, write, share work, trade author/book recommendations, and more!

Thursday Format:
After a round of introductions, we start out with a general, unstructured freewrite to get everyone in the writing mindset. We continue writing to a series of three or so writing prompts that usually one of the organizers has prepared before hand. Members are encouraged to share their work, or what they wrote about, for each prompt. We spend the remainder of the group working on our own separate projects, continuing work from one of the prompts, freewriting, or just chatting with each other.

When we have a piece to workshop, we often will write to two or so prompts, and then will go into a discussion of that piece. The workshop may take up the rest of the group, or may conclude with time left at the end.


Read more about workshops here.

Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
May 6, 2016

Learn How to Benefit from a New Healthcare Model 

Carmela Mancini, DO, MPH, Gold Direct Care

As business owners, we know the truth of the saying “Your health is your wealth.” But do we understand how the healthcare system is changing, and new ways to get the most benefit from it? In her talk “Healthcare with a Direct Impact,” featured speaker Dr. Carmela Mancini of Gold Direct Care in Marblehead, MA, will explain how the primary care service system has, over the last decade, abandoned the doctor-patient relationship in favor of a system dictated by insurance plans and focused on profitability. Dr. Mancini practices a healthcare model called Direct Primary Care, which focuses on quality care delivered in a personal, transparent, and cost-effective way. Come and learn how Direct Primary Care differs in cost and focus from the current system and concierge medicine. 

About the Speaker: Carmela Mancini, DO, MPH, graduated medical school from Nova Southeastern University in Fort. Lauderdale, Florida, and completed an Internal Medicine Residency at Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, MA. Previously employed as a hospitalist at Northshore Medical Center, she now works at Gold Direct Care in Marblehead, MA, as a primary care physician practicing a new healthcare model called Direct Primary Care. Dr. Mancini resides in Marblehead, but is originally from Florida. She is married with two stepchildren, and enjoys traveling, spending time with family, and watching old movies. For more information, contact Dr. Mancini at [masked] or visit www.golddirectcare.com.

results.description:
Big Data, Health Law, and Bioethics - Sponsored by the Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology, and Bioethics at Harvard Law School 

Event link and full schedule HERE. Register HERE. This conference is free and open to the public, but seating is limited and registration is requested. A continental breakfast (& lunch) will be provided.

May 6, 2016 

Harvard Law School, 1585 Mass. Ave.


Wasserstein Hall, Milstein East ABC

:: :: ::

The Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology, and Bioethics at Harvard Law School is pleased to announce plans for our 2016 annual conference, entitled: “Big Data, Health Law, and Bioethics.”  This year’s conference is organized in collaboration with the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard University and the Health Ethics and Policy Lab, University of Zurich. 

:: :: ::

Conference Description: “Big Data” is a phrase that has been used pervasively by the media and the lay public in the last several years. While many definitions are possible, the common denominator seems to include the “three V’s” – Volume (vast amounts of data), Variety (significant heterogeneity in the type of data available in the set), and Velocity (speed at which a data scientist or user can access and analyze the data).

Defined as such, health care has become one of the key emerging use cases for big data. For example, Fitbit and Apple’s ResearchKit can provide researchers access to vast stores of biometric data on users from which to test hypotheses on nutrition, fitness, disease progression, treatment success, and the like. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) have vast stores of billing data that can be mined to promote high value care and prevent fraud; the same is true of private health insurers.  And hospitals have attempted to reduce re-admission rates by targeting patients that predictive algorithms indicate are at highest risk based on analysis of available data collected from existing patient records.

Underlying these and many other potential uses, however, are a series of legal and ethical challenges relating to, among other things, privacy, discrimination, intellectual property, tort, and informed consent, as well as research and clinical ethics.

This conference, and anticipated edited volume, will aim to: (1) identify the various ways in which law and ethics intersect with the use of big data in health care and health research, particularly in the United States; (2) understand the way U.S. law (and potentially other legal systems) currently promotes or stands as an obstacle to these potential uses; (3) determine what might be learned from the legal and ethical treatment of uses of big data in other sectors and countries; and (4) examine potential solutions (industry best practices, common law, legislative, executive, domestic and international) for better use of big data in health care and health research in the U.S. 

All panels will include time for audience Q & A.
results.name: Big Data, Health Law, and Bioethics (HLS Conference)

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Cannabis Society has been invited by MPAA to attend the Medical Cannabis Patient Symposium on May 6.   We will bring together the entire cannabis community to engage in some social networking and to learn about the Massachusetts medical marijuana program, how to access care, what illnesses and symptoms are amenable to treatment and how best to use this medicine. Special emphasis will be placed on issues confronting aging individuals. Refreshments and a question and answer session included.

Don't forget to signup for the MPAA newsletter for the latest events and info. http://www.compassionforpatients.com/join

Featured Speakers

Nichole Snow
Executive Director of Massachusetts Patient Advocacy Alliance

Dr. Jordan Tishler
Founder of Inhale MD Health & Wellness


Jeremiah MacKinnon
MPAA Advisory Board Member                                                       

Monique Pichette
Marine, Nurse, and Founder of Nique-Wear

Michael Bourque
Engineer and Inventor of the CannaCloud Vaporizer


Stephen Mandile
Founder of Veterans Alternative Healing


Event Agenda
5:00pm Networking & Refreshments
5:20pm Nichole Snow, MPAA
5:40pm Dr. Jordan Tishler, Inhale MD
6:10pm Monique Pichette
6:30pm Michael Bourque & Stephen Mandile 6:40pm Networking & Conclusion


Event FAQ
What is the Massachusetts Patient Advocacy Alliance?
Massachusetts Patient Advocacy Alliance represents the coalition of patients, providers and organizations that worked together to pass the ballot measure Question 3 in 2012 to legalize medical marijuana and establish a safely regulated medical marijuana program throughout the Commonwealth. MPAA is the primary stakeholder regarding the implementation of the Massachusetts medical marijuana program and we work with our base of over 15,000 supporters to impact safe access through educational endeavors and direct advocacy in cities and towns across MA. http://www.compassionforpatients.com/ 

Is this event open to the public? Yes this event is free to attend for anyone interested in learning about the medical marijuana program in Massachusetts.

Who Attends? We welcome everyone to attend interested in learning about cannabis as medicine, where to access medical marijuana, and how individuals and family members can help their loved ones access medical cannabis. 

What are my transportation/parking options? We always recommend taking public transportation. Street parking is not guaranteed so please plan accordingly. For more options please go to Parkopedia for more information: http://en.parkopedia.com/parking/%3A_93_winchester_st_brookline_ma_02446/

Why should I attend? We encourage everyone to attend who thinks they might be a candidate for medical marijuana or their loved one might benefit from cannabis. Information is power and learning about medical cannabis and its benefits can lead to positive outcomes in many instances for patients suffering from a wide range of debilitating conditions. 

Want us to host a Patient Symposium near you?
We plan on having Patient Night once a month in various locations around Massachusetts. If you're interested in sponsoring this event or supporting future Patient Symposium events in different locations around the state, please email Nichole Snow at [masked]

How can I get the most from this event? This is an informational event and one may want to bring some paper and pen or pencil to write down specific information shared by the presenters speaking. If you plan on networking you should bring a business card or some other way for attendees to contact you following the event. 

Instagram / Twitter / Facebook Tips
One of the best ways to connect with fellow participants at our events is to use common hashtags when tweeting, facebooking, or instagramming about the event. Don't forget to take photos and share them with everyone using the hastags below.
#MassPatients #RememberSafeAccess #SafeAccessNow #PatientsFirst#MMJFirst

Legal Disclaimer 
Views or opinions expressed by speakers or sponsors at our local Massachusetts Patient Advocacy Alliance (MPAA) educational events do not necessarily express the opinion or views of the MPAA organization or MPAA Foundation and we do not take responsibility for the views expressed or the actions of speakers or sponsors at our local events. The MPAA does not distribute cannabis in any form at our events.

The Cannabis Society is Growing  
Our group has grown by leaps and bounds these past few years and we are proud to announce that the Cannabis Society is going to continue to grow and develop our ecosystem with groundbreaking events centering around medical cannabis, technology, art, and science. We couldn’t do it without our members and we want to thank you for being apart of this growing organization.
results.name: Medical Cannabis Patient Symposium

MFA First Friday Social Art Evening Museum of Fine Arts (West Wing Information room),Address: 465 Huntington Ave, Boston, MA 02115 tel[masked]


<------

Save wait time in line by entering the rear (Fenway )entrance of the MFA since the front gets busy.

<---------

ORGANIZER: Jimmy will be at one of the back tables at the MFA Ruth and Carl J. Shapiro Family Courtyard.

TARGET AUDIENCE: All Members of ALL AGES that like Art and a relaxed social atmosphere!

Admission: $25 per person -- Free for MFA Members. ...If you are an MFA members please try to arrange through comments to help get other members of our group in as your guest for free. You can also try to get a discount pass at your local library get you in for free or $10 a Person. Hey we all need to save a few bucks for drink later right?

Drop off your coats, buy your entry tickets and meet us all at the SHARF VISITOR CENTER at 5:45PM. After that try to find us in the Ruth and Carl J. Shapiro Family Courtyard its where the party is at. and it the big tall room with the huge green glass Chihuly art piece is in. Stay as long as you want. MFA First Fridays ends at 9PM the Museum closed at 9:45PM.

MFA First Fridays is on the first Friday of each month from 6:00–9:30 pm. Join us for fine art, music, cash bars featuring signature cocktails, and delicious tapas available for purchase. Open to visitors 21+. Valid ID with proof of age required for entry.

Accepted forms of identification for First Friday entrance include:
Massachusetts Drivers License
Massachusetts Liquor ID
Massachusetts ID issued by the Massachusetts Registry of Motor Vehicles
Drivers License from any US state
Valid Passport (photocopies are not accepted)
Federal Identification (e.g. Military ID)

We can mix and mingle with fellow art lovers,  enjoy the art,  the music and sip on our lovely drinks. hen we can break off and look at some more art since the rest of the museum is open!

Hope you can make it out this fine Friday Evening out for some Art Culture and great conversations.

======================================================

Notes for Parking for the MFA: It will be busy and lots tend to fill up fast so try to get there early! Taking the T is your best bet!

Self Parking Options: Visitors to the MFA have three self-parking options: the Huntington Lot, the Fenway Lot, and the Museum Road Garage, all of which have entrances on Museum Road. The Huntington lot offers closer parking to the Huntington Avenue Entrance and the Fenway parking lot is more accessible to the State Street Corporation Fenway Entrance. MFA lost Park costs $$$ over $20 so be prepared.

Subway Take the Green Line E train to the Museum of Fine Arts stop, or the Orange Line train to the Ruggles stop.

venue.name: Shim Gwang Sa- Mind Light Temple and Zen Martial Arts Center

results.description:
Great Zen Master Chang Sik Kim is the founding master of the Zen Buddhist martial art known as Shim Gum Do. He is also the founder of the Shim Gwang Sa, or Mind Light Temple in Brighton, MA, home to the World Shim Gum Do Association. A lauded calligrapher and Zen poet, Master Kim has published sixteen Zen poetry books. 

The first Friday meditation is held in the traditional Zen Buddhist style and lasts 45 minutes. The dharma talk, or teaching talk, by Master Kim follows immediately after. There is no charge for the meditation or talk. 

For more information http://www.shimgumdo.org or (617) 787-1506.
results.name: First Friday Zen Dharma Talk
