The weather does seem to be against us for the outside yard games, so if the sun doesn't appear this afternoon I have a Plan B.  Check you email or send an email to [masked] for the update.

Please update your RSVP.

Thanks,

FWF


  PLEASE READ ALL OF THE INFORMATION BELOW.

As you enter the park, turn LEFT and follow the route towards the MAIN BEACH AREA. There is very large parking lot at the Main Beach Area and several others close by.  See the map below with all the details.

PLEASE don't be late and if you have signed up to join us and your plans have changed, be UPDATE your RSVP so others that may be on the WAITLIST can attend.

Outdoor yards games and hike may be happening at the same time. So do whatever you prefer or both.  Volunteers needed to lead the hikes.

 See the map below for the exact meet-up location.

For the online map - click the link below.

http://www.mass.gov/eea/docs/dcr/parks/trails/hopkinton.pdf

Note: There is NO Alcohol allowed nor any littering at the State Park.

Public Bathrooms will be available on the premises.

What you might what to bring:

• Lawn Chairs 

• Water and snacks to munch on! 

• Any outdoor yards games you have on hand 

• A BIG Smile :-)) 

.............................................................................................................................

What will I be bringing? 

• Water and snacks to munch on!

• A BIG Smile  :-)) 

• Kite - Hopefully it will be windy this time.

• Some of the outdoor yard games shown below.

See the instructions and video of how to play the game. If the games are of interest please take the time to learn as much about the game as possible before you arrive.  It's been several years since I've played some of these games and I don't remember as much as I use too :-)!

Have you ever play Kubb?

Kubb is a lawn game where the object is to knock over wooden blocks by throwing wooden sticks at them. Kubb can be simply described as a combination of bowling and horseshoes. The ultimate object of the game is to knock the "king" over, before the opponent does.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=liMZ-dFMJSc

How about Cornhole?

Scoring is simple. After all bags have been thrown, a bag remaining on the board is worth 1 point. A bag that went in the hole is worth 3 points. Add up how many points you earned and compare them to your opponents. Equal points cancel each other out so that only one team can score per round. For example, if you scored 5 points and your opponent scored 3, you will add 2 points to your overall score and your team will throw first in the next round. If you scored 6 points and your opponent scored 6 as well, there will be no points awarded and whoever threw first in the last round will throw first again. A game is won when a team reaches 21 points with a lead of 2 or more points. The first team to win 2 games wins the match.

Ladder Game

Ladder Game, space the game ladders about 15 feet apart and start tossing your bolas. Each player tosses all 3 bolas, then the next player tosses all 3 bolas. The first one to 21 without going over is the winner! The top rung is worth 3 points, middle is 2 and bottom rung is 1 point.

Horsehoes 

Horsehoes, there are two ways to score: by throwing "ringers" or by throwing the horseshoe nearest to the stake. A ringer is a thrown horseshoe such that the horseshoe completely encircles the stake. Disputes are settled by using astraightedge to touch the two points at the ends of the horseshoe, called "heel calks". If the straightedge doesn't touch the stake, then the horseshoe is a ringer. 

Kickball - Let's act like kids again and have some fun playing this game!   

Questions or want my contact information? (cell phone number in case you can't find our group.  I don't want to post my cell phone number on this site, but will email to you.  Just send your request to: [masked]  Let's have some fun and be sure to sign-up for the next FWF event on June 12th. 

FWF (Fun With Friends) has LIMITED NUMBER of box seats on sale right now ($15.00 per ticket) for Pawsox Baseball Game on Sunday at McCoy Stadium 1:05 PM. 

Organizer assumes no liability either before, during, or after this event.

HOPKINTON STATE PARK DIRECTIONS:

• From the north: 
Take Route I-495 South towards Marlboro/Taunton 
Take exit 21A to Main Street Hopkinton. 
Travel down Main Street until the third traffic light located at the heart of downtown Hopkinton 
Turn left, traveling North on Route 85 
After about two miles, the Hopkinton State Park entrance should be on the right

• From the south: 
Take Route I-495 North 
Take exit 21A to Main Street Hopkinton. 
Travel down Main Street until the third traffic light located at the heart of downtown Hopkinton 
Turn left, traveling North on Route 85 
After about two miles, the Hopkinton State Park entrance should be on the right

• From the East: 
Route 90 (Mass Pike West) to Route 495 South 
Take exit 21A to Main Street Hopkinton. 
Travel down Main Street until the third traffic light located at the heart of downtown Hopkinton 
Turn left, traveling North on Route 85 
After about two miles, the Hopkinton State Park entrance should be on the right

results.description:
Our first show!

Lilypad is a public venue in Inman Square. It can hold up to 90 people. We will have the doors open, so hopefully we will even get some people off the street to play music with us.

I did/will devise a system for substituting players (this is the "scramble"). At any time, 4 players will play. There will always be someone on drums, someone on bass, and two people on other instruments (guitar, violin, keys, clarinet, flute, etc.). Every 3 minutes, one of the players will substitute, so that each player plays for 12 minutes at a time.

The show will be free to watch, but I will request small donations from those who play. Please bring along anyone you know who might be interested.

We do have to watch our volume to some extent (so if I tell you to turn down, do it). The 3-hour timeslot includes setup and takedown, so try to be prompt. Lilypad supplies drums, PA, mixer, and amps. Let me know if I'm forgetting anything important in this description. Parking around Inman Square can be difficult! Be sure to schedule plenty of time for parking and walking.

Remember, the goal is to play with minimal discussion. Listen; try something while listening; listen; try it again while listening; if it sounds good, repeat with variation. Let's have fun!
results.name: Scramble at Lilypad (Inman Square)

Note: 

There will be no face to face meetup unless we reach 50 RSVPs by Thursday of the week. You must be enrolled in one of the 10 FREE courses below or similar courses. 

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

http://www.tutorteddy.com/courses/coursera-course-help.php 

You can get help for the following Data Science Specialization Classes:  (from https://www.coursera.org/specialization/jhudatascience/1?utm_medium=courseDescripTop )

The Data Scientist’s Toolbox

R Programming

Getting and Cleaning Data

Exploratory Data Analysis

Reproducible Research

Statistical Inference

Regression Models

Practical Machine Learning

Developing Data Products

Data Science Capstone

Part 4 (Final event for spring '16)

Introductory programming course, using Scratch.


When signing up, please indicate the number of kids you will be bringing. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Accurate headcounts are very helpful for planning purposes, and help us deliver the best learning experience possible.
results.name: Beginner Scratch (4 of 4)

results.description:
Part 4 (Final event for spring '16)

This session is designed for students who have already taken an intro to Python, Java, C/C++, or Javascript course (programming beyond HTML/CSS or Scratch). Exceptions may be granted with instructor permission. Students should be familiar with variables, if statements, and loops. Please arrive prepared with a laptop that already has Python (including scipy, numpy, and matlplotlib packages) installed and running: https://www.python.org/downloads/. If you are new to Python and don't have an environment like Spyder or PyCharm already set up, please use IPython Notebook (http://ipython.org/notebook.html).

The focus of this session will be making music with Python. Depending on student interest and ability, we may cover how computers play music files, how we can create our own digital music, how we can use the computer to distort existing music in cool ways, and ultimately how to make our own music using Python. Under the broader umbrella of digital signal processing, we can also explore topics from speech recognition to medical imaging.

When signing up, please indicate the number of kids you will be bringing. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Accurate headcounts are very helpful for planning purposes, and help us deliver the best learning experience possible.

If possible, please email [masked]a brief summary of your student's programming experience and interests. Students are encouraged to explore the online documentation themselves and experiment with running their own code before class.

results.description:
You are cordially invited to a Kentucky Derby Brunch  on Saturday, May 7th 


1:30 PM to 5:00 PM at Club Cafe 


The afternoon includes: 

• Brunch/Lunch (al la carte)  & Other libations 

• Door and Best  Hat/Attire Prizes (Dapper Derby attire is encouraged; however , not required.)

•  Kentucky Derby  

Please obtain your tickets by May 5th if you are able to attend. (space is limited)


Details regarding Kentucky Derby attire are listed below. For brunch, consider the following :  

Gentlemen/ish, here's your chance to steal the show! Go all out for  Brunch  and sport a seersucker or three-piece tweed suit. Top it off with a fedora or bowler hat and ground your look with loafers.


Ladies/Ladylike, A pantsuit, cocktail dress or business formal attire is recommended. Of course, you'll want to accessorize accordingly. Pearls, a  clutch and a stunning Derby hat are a must!


Hats/Fascinators!


From the fantastic to the sublime, there are no rules or limits when it comes to choosing your Derby hat.


Wearing a hat to the Kentucky Derby is believed to bear good luck! The long-established fashion was started by the women, however, over the last few years, many men have taken part in the tradition as well. Wearing a hat is much like getting into costume, you might be pleasantly surprised to see what type of character you become. 


Generally speaking, wide-brimmed, "Southern Belle" inspired Kentucky Derby hats. The hats can be decorated with flowers, feathers, bows and ribbons of any color to express creativity and individuality.A more recent trend in Kentucky Derby headwear is the fascinator. Smaller than a traditional hat and just as stylish, this piece of headwear has become more popular among Kentucky Derby attendees over recent years.


 Wardrobe (Ladies & Gents)


 The event is an opportunity to showcase your finest spring look. Both female and male attendees pull out all of the stops when selecting their Kentucky Derby apparel.


 There are no hard and fast rules when it comes to Derby dressing,  ladies typically wear spring dresses, pastel-colored suits, or bold separates that coordinate with their Derby headwear and accessories.


 The Kentucky Derby is a chance for every female to express her inner Southern Belle so take note and don't hold back when planning your Kentucky Derby wardrobe!


When selecting your dress for the Kentucky Derby the recommended practice is to keep it simple, so it doesn't take away from your hat. You can also let the color and excitement of spring inspire you and select a dress full of color, or floral or equine patterns.


Starting with the pants because it is the eye-catcher from a distance, gents should turn to sun drenched pants in vibrant colors like Key Lime, Ocean, Bermuda Pink, and Citron. Any one of these colors paired with the right shirt and blazer will make you stand out like no one else.


 Now that you have the pants you know that you're going to have some fun with the shirts. A great dress shirt in a complimentary color will go a long way. Don't be afraid to grab a fun gingham or striped shirt to turn it up. This is the one day of the year that more is better. One option that is a must for some is the monogram on the shirt!


 The jacket is what brings everything together and you can't go wrong with the classic navy blazer. If you want to have a little fun on top though, a nice chalk stripe can really make the ladies' big hats turn. As far as 2- button or 3-button it's a person preference but we recommend sporting the 3- button side vent for a more polished look.


Next is the tie. Most gentlemen wear a necktie, but a bow tie is always a great option. If you never wear bows, try it out and you may like it. 


For shoes, there are many types of horse bit loafers out there and everyone has their idea of who makes the best ones. The most important thing you need to know is that they should be worn sockless.


 Top it all off with a fedora or bowler hat for the complete Kentucky Derby look. Men's Derby hats are generally solid in color and inspired by the style from the 1920s.
results.name: Kentucky Derby Brunch

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 1:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 1:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 4pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Sat May 7, 1:30-4pm)

results.description:
I'm not sure what the theme for this week will be yet, but come join us for swimming! All levels are welcome, but you should be comfortable swimming at least a couple of lengths continuously.


We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.


---------------


The pool opens at 2pm, so we meet to go in at 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)

For more information contact [masked]
or see all the information below. NOTE! There is a special NCL sale that ends 1/31- if you book by then you can pick any two of the following three.

* FREE DRINK PACKAGE

Can we buy you a drink? How about all of them? Get free glasses of wine, beer, spirits, cocktails, juices, and soda for your entire cruise vacation.

* ONBOARD CREDIT for up to $300 (depending on room category) If you book your trip with us to the Greek Isles you can choose any two of the following (this is for other cruises as well)

All prices per person based on double occupancy- please ask for Quote for 3rd and 4th person. (price does not include flight to Venice) NOTE NCL will be having a sale starting Feb 1 where 3rd and 4th guest in a cabin are free!

Inside- $1,[masked]

For those interested we will add a pre-cruise itinerary in Venice before the cruise. Carla King, the travel agent will personalize the vacation to meet your needs.

With year-round Mediterranean cruise itineraries, Norwegian Jade is the perfect way to explore the pyramids, castles, cathedrals, romantic islands and sophisticated cities of Europe. And as you cruise from port to port along stunning coastlines, we’ll keep you entertained day and night with exciting nightclubs, award-winning restaurants, a grand casino, swimming pools, a pampering spa and so much more. There’s tons of fun for kids too, so bring the whole family, and enjoy the European cruise adventure of a lifetime. It's no wonder we are the seven-time World Travel Award winner for "Europe's Leading Cruise Line."

Island hop your way through the romantic Greek Isles and explore the shimmering waterways around the Mediterranean. On this sailing, cruisers can traverse the canals of Venice in a gondola, hear the echoes of ancient Olympians in Katakolon and explore the caves of Paleokastritsa in Corfu. Onboard, nestle in your cabin for a nice nap or lounge poolside with a cocktail.


Day 1 Venice, Italy (EMBARK)
--- 6:00 pm Venice, Italy You could start a discussion about Venice by praising its restaurants, wine bars, marble churches or blown glass. But you probably won't. You'll likely start with the fact that Venice is built on water. It is a place where people either float slowly down palace-lined man-made waterways or stroll down narrow alleyways. There's no more extraordinary place to find yourself, or lose yourself. Be sure to stay in Venice before your next European cruise.

Day 2 At Sea --- ---

Day 3 Corfu, Greece
8:00 am 3:30 pm Corfu, Greece One of the lushest of the Greek Isles, Corfu is rimmed in dramatic blue waters and topped with tranquil hillside villages. A collection of quaint cafes in the town of Corfu feels very continental, but the island's secluded coves and sandy beaches could only be found in the Greek Isles. Explore more of Corfu on a European cruise!

Day 4 Santorini, Greece
1:30 pm 10:00 pm Santorini, Greece Whitewashed villages clinging to the sides of the sea cliffs have made the volcanic island of Santorini one of the most widely photographed places in the world. The island's charm and subtle mystery have even made it a target of speculation as the location of the lost city of Atlantis.

Day 5 Mykonos, Greece
8:00 am 6:00 pm Mykonos, Greece Mykonos is a classic Greek Island with whitewashed houses, blue-domed churches and windmills. Add a reputation for beautiful beaches and you'll understand why Mykonos is the most popular island in the Cyclades. Explore the island in a 4 x 4 or take a ferry to the tiny island of Delos. Explore more of Mykonos on a European cruise!

Day 6 Olympia (Katakolon), Greece
9:00 am 6:00 pm Olympia (Katakolon), Greece This quaint little seaside town on the Ionian Sea is the gateway to Ancient Olympia, where Greek mythology was born and the first Olympiad was held. You may still be able to hear the distant echoes of the ancient Greeks cheering as you tour the ruins of one of the most important and exciting sanctuaries of antiquity. Explore more of Katakolon on a European cruise!

Day 7 At Sea --- ---
Day 8 Venice, Italy (DISEMBARK)
8:00 am ---

results.description:
May 7, 2016

Celebrate Spring, and Celebrate Rock ‘n’ Roll Radio!

DJ Easy Ed Presents: A Huge Rockin’ Live Show to Mark the Tenth Anniversary of “Easy Ed’s Variety Show” on WMFO in Medford! May 7 at the Midway in Jamaica Plain

This is a day/night show with a fantastic line up of bands, DJs, and special guests!

Some said it wouldn’t last two weeks, but, somehow, “Easy Ed’s Variety Hour”—the rockabilly radio show that blasts worldwide on WMFO in Medford, MA—turns ten this spring. Come on out and celebrate with us! We’ve got a killer diller day/night event planned and a lineup that can’t be beat. The bands and guests on the bill represent everything that “Easy Ed’s Variety Hour” is all about—Rockabilly, Hillbilly, R&B, and Rock ‘n’ Roll! Don’t miss this once-in-a-lifetime celebration, with

The Cranktones!
Johnny Carlevale and His Band of All Stars (Special Reunion Show)!
The Barley Hoppers!
The Bop Thrills!
The Fearless Leaders!
Easy Ed's Record Hop
Special guests Roy Sludge and DJ Kogar the Swinging Ape!

See the Facebook event page for more information and updates--and advance ticket info: https://www.facebook.com/events/192325004458867/

The legendary Cranktones are veterans of the New England rockabilly scene, and they’ve been wowing roots music fans for over twenty years. This classic rockin’ trio comprises “Cranky” Frankie Blandino on guitar, Stan Kozlowski on drums, and Johnny Sciascia slappin' the bass. They’ll be pulling out all the stops for this very special night of rock ‘n’ roll. Easy Ed played the Cranktones on his very first broadcast and continues to feature the band regularly on his show.
https://www.facebook.com/cranktones/?fref=ts

We’re hugely excited to present a reunion of Johnny Carlevale and His Band of All Stars, the renowned Jump Blues/R&B outfit that tore up many a stage before going on break for several years. This will be their first performance in a very long time and they boys are ready to jump and swing. You will be too when you hear their fantastic set of rhythm and blues. Johnny Carlevale has performed on Easy Ed’s show many times and has been a featured act at numerous live Easy Ed shows!
https://myspace.com/brokenrhythmboys/music/songs

Providence’s Barley Hoppers--featuring Stan “the Man” Kozlowski on rhythm guitar and lead vocals, Ray Reniere on lead guitar, and Steve Bigelow on bass—play classic country, rockabilly, and rock ‘n’ roll. Wear your dancin’ shoes—these guys fill the dance floor right quick! The Barley Hoppers and Easy Ed have a special connection, as he was the first DJ to play selections from their CD on the radio. The band has also performed live in the WMFO studio.
https://www.facebook.com/The-Barley-Hoppers-159348070822160/

Jeff Deware and the Bop Thrills are an exciting, high-energy, traditional rockabilly band from Rhode Island—and an Easy Ed favorite. Their infectious sounds have impressed fans, DJs, and critics alike. They can really tear it up. Don’t miss ‘em!

https://www.facebook.com/Jeff-Deware-The-BopThrills-414605055360870/

The Fearless Leaders are a fantastic rock 'n' roll band from Worcester, MA! They play rockabilly, rock 'n' roll, mersey beat, western swing and more. In short, they are everything that "Easy Ed's Variety Hour" is all about. https://www.facebook.com/TheFearlessLeaders/?fref=ts


+Easy Ed’s Record Hop and guest DJs

With Additional Performances by Special Surprise Guests (TBA)!


https://www.facebook.com/Easy-Eds-Variety-Hour-on-WMFO-177813815586257/?ref=hl

www.easy-ed.net
results.name: Easy Ed’s Variety Hour Tenth Anniversary Party--6 Bands+ Rockin' Record Hops!

Lynn woods is vast and the trails are rocky and hilly. It's a wonderful place to walk and offers great views. Please be prepared to walk on rugged and woodsy terrain.

Coming from RT 1 North or South, take the RT 129 East / Salem Street Exit. Continue down RT129/Salem Street to the traffic rotary bearing right following RT129 which turns into Lynnfield Street. Follow this for about 1 mile and turn right onto Great Woods Road. Following Great Woods Road to the end which becomes the Ballfield Parking Lot.

I plan on meticulously arranging the best excursions and activities possible, that all will be optional. So come join me for the best cruise of the Greek islands.

You'll likely start with the fact that Venice is built on water. It is a place where people either float slowly down palace-lined man-made waterways or stroll down narrow alleyways. There's no more extraordinary place to find yourself, or lose yourself. Be sure to stay in Venice before your next European cruise.

Day 2 At Sea --- ---

Day 3 Corfu, Greece 

8:00 am 3:30 pm Corfu, Greece One of the lushest of the Greek Isles, Corfu is rimmed in dramatic blue waters and topped with tranquil hillside villages. A collection of quaint cafes in the town of Corfu feels very continental, but the island's secluded coves and sandy beaches could only be found in the Greek Isles. Explore more of Corfu on a European cruise!

Day 4 Santorini, Greece 

1:30 pm 10:00 pm Santorini, Greece Whitewashed villages clinging to the sides of the sea cliffs have made the volcanic island of Santorini one of the most widely photographed places in the world. The island's charm and subtle mystery have even made it a target of speculation as the location of the lost city of Atlantis. 

Day 5 Mykonos, Greece  

8:00 am 6:00 pm Mykonos, Greece Mykonos is a classic Greek Island with whitewashed houses, blue-domed churches and windmills. Add a reputation for beautiful beaches and you'll understand why Mykonos is the most popular island in the Cyclades. Explore the island in a 4 x 4 or take a ferry to the tiny island of Delos. Explore more of Mykonos on a European cruise!

Day 6 Olympia (Katakolon), Greece  

9:00 am 6:00 pm Olympia (Katakolon), Greece This quaint little seaside town on the Ionian Sea is the gateway to Ancient Olympia, where Greek mythology was born and the first Olympiad was held. You may still be able to hear the distant echoes of the ancient Greeks cheering as you tour the ruins of one of the most important and exciting sanctuaries of antiquity. Explore more of Katakolon on a European cruise!

Day 7 At Sea --- --- 

Day 8 Venice, Italy (DISEMBARK)  

8:00 am ---

NOTE: There are various offers and special NCL sales that will be offered at various times till the cruise takes place, ALL THOUGH WILL HAVE DEADLINES. Make sure you take advantage of them.

For more information contact [masked] 

 INFORMATIVE DINNERS EVERY MONTH TILL CRUISE

 If you would like to join us for this amazing trip make sure you attend some of the informative dinners we will be hosting.  At the dinners all interested in the cruise can get a chance to meet before hand and ask any questions they may have regarding the cruise. Keep a watch out for the dinners!

 *No strings attached to go on cruise to attend the dinners.

PRICES FOR CRUISE ONLY 

All prices per person based on double occupancy- please ask for Quote for 3rd and 4th person. (price does not include flight to Venice) 

NOTE NCL will be having a sale starting Feb 1 where 3rd and 4th guest in a cabin are free!

Balcony - $1,841.90 
Ocean view- $1,381.90 
Inside- $1,[masked]

For those interested we will add a pre-cruise itinerary in Venice before the cruise. Carla King, the travel agent will personalize the vacation to meet your needs.

With year-round Mediterranean cruise itineraries, Norwegian Jade is the perfect way to explore the pyramids, castles, cathedrals, romantic islands and sophisticated cities of Europe. And as you cruise from port to port along stunning coastlines, we’ll keep you entertained day and night with exciting nightclubs, award-winning restaurants, a grand casino, swimming pools, a pampering spa and so much more. There’s tons of fun for kids too, so bring the whole family, and enjoy the European cruise adventure of a lifetime. It's no wonder we are the seven-time World Travel Award winner for "Europe's Leading Cruise Line."

Island hop your way through the romantic Greek Isles and explore the shimmering waterways around the Mediterranean. On this sailing, cruisers can traverse the canals of Venice in a gondola, hear the echoes of ancient Olympians in Katakolon and explore the caves of Paleokastritsa in Corfu. Onboard, nestle in your cabin for a nice nap or lounge poolside with a cocktail.

results.description:
DERBY DAY

Join us for a day of fun  - Kentucky Derby Style

May 7th starting at 4:30pm

Come to the races enjoy the day of The Kentucky Derby

6 Live Races  *  $2.00 Bets   *  Daily Doubles

Prizes for the best dressed and best Derby Hat

Bring you own snacks (Elks does not sell food but you can order take out or bring food in:)

You need to gain entry with a member, call me when you arrive if you'd like to join us.

When attending this event you are subject to Meetups terms and conditions as well as this meetups terms and conditions, both of which accept no responsibility for you when you attend any of our events, nor does the Elks.  Please drink responsibly and always consider a cab or Uber for rides home.

Please be respectful of venue and organizer, no same day cancellations and no shows will be marked accordingly.  We want to continue to offer these fun events to the Elks and be welcomed to do so, if you rsvp your coming please honor your rsvp.

results.description:
I have made a reservation for the latest room at Escape the Room ("The Apartment"). This event is in downtown Boston. Unfortunately, this event is limited to 8 people.

Dinner to follow afterward. If you do not wish to join dinner, please let the group know, thanks!


Escape the Room is a fun, interactive game taking place in Boston. While it looks like any other ordinary room, it’s actually a mystery puzzle. Find the hidden objects, figure out the clues and solve the puzzles to earn your freedom and “Escape the Room.”
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet at the venue at 5 PM (or we can take the T or car together there)
results.name: *FULL* Arlington Escapes the Room - The Apartment

results.description:
Hi everyone! 

In our April 2nd Bible Study, the group decided on the topic of Evangelism for the May 7th study.

- Should we as Christians evangelize?

- How important is it for us to be involved in evangelism?

- What should be our approach to evangelism?  What is God's Spirit guiding us to do? 

- How should we evangelize?  What approaches would be most effective?

I think the discussion from all of you will be a very important part of this topic as we apply the Bible to our modern lives, culture and context.

You're always welcome to come to any Bible Studies that fit your schedule. The studies will be structured as independent sessions, so you won't be lost if you miss one!

Future Bible studies would be bi-weekly on the 1st and 3rd Saturday's each month, at the same time and location, with the topics determined by you! 

We're also scheduling separate bi-weekly Bible studies for the 2nd and 4th Saturdays of each month which may have more content around dating, marriage and family life.

I hope you can join us!
results.name: 1st & 3rd Saturday Bible Study:  "Evangelism in the Modern World"

results.description:
I've had this idea tucked away for awhile. Its time!

Let's get together to cook up some fabulous home-made pizza (or flatbread) and find the perfect wine pairings to go with! 

There are very few foods as versatile and comforting as a freshly made pizza.  Classic Margherita with red sauce, mozzarella and basil, or Porchetta with fennel roasted pork, fontina, asiago and red onion. Maybe a  green pesto version with goat cheese, broccoli and walnuts, or a roast Apple one, with gorgonzola, bacon and caramelized onions. Or as we had a Viale, a seafood pizza with fiery calamari.

Its making me famished just thinking about it! 


PRICE

Cost: $10 w/RSVP for food 

Your fee will cover the cost of all food. 

Usual BostonWine refund policy applies. I will refund 100% up to 1 day in advance of the event. After that time, no refund. We are now using Meetup's payment service WePay. Let Jim know if there are any issues.

==> READ THIS! The event starts promptly at 5:00 PM, so please be on time.  Greeters will be on hand from 5:00 - 6:00 PM. Security is tight and access shuts down at 6:00 PM. You won't be able to get in if late!  <==

POLICIES

NOTE: As part of the RSVP process you will be asked to accept the group's Policies and Disclaimer (use a new web browser window to see the "About Us" section of our group's home page). Then click on RSVP for this event and answer "Yes" to the policy question--You must accept policies as part of your RSVP for each event that you attend. (Note, apparently some versions of the Meetup mobile app don't display this question -- in that case, RSVP with your phone and then use a web browser later on to update your RSVP). 

WINE

Please bring a bottle of your favorite pizza wine, red, white, rose, sweet--your choice. In most cases this will be an inexpensive, simple but satisfying every day wine, but there is no price limit and the wine can be sourced from any country. We will vote on best wine by color independent of price.

FOOD

I will supply dough and all the toppings for the pizza. We will setup an assembly line, making a different style of pizza each time, classic, with meat, vegetarian, contemporary, wild, red sauce, green, cream! If you have a favorite recipe let me know. We can try cooking some on the grill too. Suggestions and fellow cooks welcome.

DRESS

Casual, relaxed, whatever.

WHERE

The event will be held in the Club Room of the Hanover CambridgePark apartment building near the Alewife T station. 

We have access to a demonstration kitchen, fridge, ice machine, etc. 

Hanover CambridgePark 
160 CambridgePark Drive 
Club Room, 1st floor 
Cambridge, MA 02140 

Phone:[masked]

T stop: Alewife (Red line)

Parking: Unfortunately, there is no guest parking at Hanover. Public transportation or a car service such as Uber is preferable. Otherwise, park at Alewife T station ($7). Park and walk to main lobby of 160 and follow general directions. 

ABOUT

The Hanover CambridgePark is a luxury apartment building complex in the Alewife area of Cambridge. It has a spacious club room where we'll be meeting, a spa-like pool, fitness center, pool, courtyard with fire pits, grills, high-end finishes, etc. 

For those interested in seeing a model apartment, leasing staff will be on hand before the event to do a tour (call ahead to be sure to get a spot). Remember to let them know that you're part of BostonWine. ;-) 

Looking forward to seeing you all!

-Jim

results.description:
This meet-up hosts family-friendly board game nights for those in East Cambridge and beyond. The fact that it's an inclusive group made up of singles as well as parents (with kids) makes it unique in the Greater Boston area.

Trinity Cambridge Church (www.trinitycambridge.com) sponsors our meet-up as a way to serve the Cambridge community. They pay for the upkeep of this page. Ernesto's Pizzeria also sponsors our meet-up and provides free pizza for everyone. 

We meet at the organizer's home, 217 Thorndike Street, Cambridge, which is a 10-minute walk from the Kendall and Lechmere T-stops. 


We gather every other week on Saturdays from 6-9pm. We specialize in Euro-style tabletop games of medium complexity. After grabbing some slices of pizza, we break into groups to play strategy games to entertain the adults (e.g. Dominion, Settlers of Catan, Avalon, Carcassone, Hanabi, Ticket to Ride, etc.) as well as simpler games to regale the kids (e.g. Dixit, Twirkle, Code Names, Skip-Bo, etc.). Usually, we have a volunteer or two to supervise the kids' games. If you have younger children who are not able to play the games, you will have to watch them yourself. 

Due to the limited space, you must RSVP and inform us of how many people are in your party. For this reason, we ask that you be considerate of others by RSVP'ing only if you are likely to attend. This also allows us to alert you in the event that the meet-up is cancelled.

We welcome beginners and advanced players, and you are invited to bring your own favorite games as well.

results.description:
{At the the third anniversary of PGN, we'll celebrate all the things that we continue to do over the long haul -- because we find them worthwhile ourselves and we are willing to overcome the inevitable obstacles.}

This Evening We Will ....

... celebrate the third birthday of PGN, and honor all the long-term projects, long-term relationships, long-term commitments we have kept alive in our lives -- despite the inevitable problems and excuses.

Oftentimes new ideas, new projects, new relationships, new businesses can start with big excitement, but quickly the enthusiasm ebbs and we can't find the perseverance to keep going.  We are onto the next shiny idea/project/relationship/career.

But every once in a while we find something that sticks -- in us.  It speaks to something essential in us.  We magically find the energy and power to keep going, even when obstacles and problems would otherwise give us every excuse to quit.

Thus, our long-term commitments give us a clue about what we value most.   

So what are your long-term commitments?

To Bring ...

Contribution: Potluck contribution, or $10 pp.  
This is a potluck dinner party, so bring something easy, and tasty, to eat.  (If you do not like to prepare or buy food, throw $10 per person into the pot.) 

[Optional]: Bring a friend with whom you have a long-term !

To Prepare ....

1)  What projects have you continued doing over the years? 
2) What relationships have you kept over the years?
3) What other commitments have you kept over the years?

4) What were the reasons to give up?  How did you overcome them?  What have the benefits been?
5) What does this long-term commitment say about you?
 


Our Leader This Evening

This is a Route 128 South Heartbeat Salon community event.  All of us will share the importance and the impact of those long-term projects, relationships, and commitments that we have kept doing.

Links

Most Important:   
  * Other, Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 
  * Join our Heart Conversation on FaceBook

For Newbies: 
  *  What is a Heartbeat Salon?  
  *  Where are Heartbeat Salons  
  *  Guidelines for Attending a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Hosts: 
  * How to Host a Heartbeat Salon . 
  * Topics to Offer at a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Presenters: 
  * How to Present at a Heartbeat Salon .

Your Suggestions: 
  * Give Us Your Ideas (topics, locations, etc) . 

9/03/15

results.description:
Join your sisters in sacred ceremony to bring in the New Moon -- a night that marks the beginning of a new lunar cycle. This is a powerful time to cleanse and to plant seeds of intention which will manifest as the moon grows full. Goddesses gather together and begin the circle with a group meditation. We then move into a discussion about the "astrological weather" and how these trends may relate to what we are currently feeling in our own lives. We also talk about the different energies we can call upon to manifest what we would like to invite into our lives during the next cycle. We finish the night with a pot luck Goddess hour which is always such a special end to the night. (The women this circle attracts are absolute angels and are so inspiring and heart centered. I mean this from the bottom of my heart. These nights are always such a blessing and I truly look forward to meeting you all soon!) xox With so much love and gratitude,

Ashley

results.description:
South Africa is the ninth largest producer of wine in the world. Most of South Africa's wine-producing regions have a Mediterranean climate; the abundance of mountains, valleys and plateaus allow winemakers to produce a diverse range of styles. The country's signature variety is Pinotage, a crossing of Pinot Noir and Cinsaut, which is rarely found in quantity in any other wine producing country. Shiraz, Cabernet Sauvignon, and Merlot are widely planted too. Chenin Blanc is the republic’s most-planted grape, and South African Chardonnay and Sauvignon Blanc have become popular internationally in recent years. 

I have little experience with this region and hope we bring an interesting variety to our tasting. Please bring a bottle in the $20 range in a brown paper wine bag, 4 wine glasses, and $15 cash to contribute towards food. RSVP date will begin Monday, April 11th at 7:00pm.
results.name: South African Wines

results.description:
We will visit the abandoned Medfield State Hospital for some urban exploration. This is a fairly large complex of an old "lunatic hospital", one of many such institutions that we used to segregate mentally ill patients, only 50 years ago. Since it became politically incorrect in the 1970s, Massachusetts has shuttered many such (often very beautiful) buildings. This is one still standing and quite solidly so. All buildings are boarded up and we will NOT attempt to go inside any of these, but rather roam around the outside and try to capture the haunting character of this location.


Please don't be late and meet us on-time at the GPS coordinates above, we will need to check in with the local police and move as one group. We will also leave at the same time, around three hours later (but you can leave earlier). This will be a popular event, please do not sign up unless you are sure that you can make it. Day-of-event cancellations will be marked as no-shows. Paid members only. RAIN DATE: Sunday, the day after.

Suggested equipment: wide to super-wide angle lenses, as you will be rather close to the buildings and they are large. Dress appropriately for the weather and wear hiking books, it is uneven terrain.


The sun sets at 7:35, we will have twilight left when we arrive to orient ourselves and this is a moonless night for added spook (ghosts, anyone?). If weather cooperates, we can shoot star trails.
results.name: Urbex: Medfield State Hospital

Meet to paint the model for a five week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $75 or $90 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

I-Opener: Morning Community Ecstatic Dance

Join our Mother's Day I-Opener Dance. Let’s get together. Let’s dance. Let’s make art. Let’s celebrate our community and especially all the mothers around us.


Chandra Cantor will help us ground and stretch our bodies with yoga. Inspired special guest DJ Hip Sockit (Brando) will lead us through ecstatic dance journey. 


Admission: 10$ - 15$, kids under 15 years free


Great way to start your Sunday. If you want to hang out before and after the dance, the Armory Cafe will be open. 

Plenty of free parking space behind the building.

The uplifted dancing space is considered to be sacred. We abstain from social talk, and we dance without shoes. The event is drug/alcohol free. You may participate in the dance or just enjoy witnessing. Children are welcome.If you know anyone else who would enjoy this dance, please forward them this email.Join us on Facebook

results.description:
The Friends of the Public Garden, in association with the City of Boston Parks and Recreation Department, will celebrate Mother’s Day with Boston-area families during its annual Duckling Day on Sunday, May 8th.

Duckling Day Quick Facts:
Sunday, May 8, 2016
Boston Common – Parkman Bandstand
Hosted by the Friends of the Public Garden
10:00 a.m. – Registration/check-in begins
10:00 a.m. – Playtime on the Common begins
11:45 a.m. – Executive Director Liz Vizza greets families
12:00 p.m. – Parade begins

The registration fee is $35 per family online before May 6th and $40 per family the day of the event. Each child who registers will receive a special goodie bag filled with Duckling Day themed items.

Register online at https://interland3.donorperfect.net/weblink/weblink.aspx?name=ftpg&id=25

For nearby parking information please visit the website of our lead sponsor: Motor Mart Garage

A beloved tradition for more than 30 years, Duckling Day celebrates the children’s classic book, “Make Way for Ducklings” by Robert McCloskey. Every year, over 1,000 people meet up and parade through Boston’s most picturesque parks, dressed like characters from the story. Led by the Harvard Marching Band, the parade will begin on the Boston Common at the Parkman Bandstand and end in the Public Garden near the famous Make Way for Ducklings sculptures. Bring your camera – the parade is possibly the most adorable thing you’ll ever see!

Prior to the parade will be Playtime on the Common, a vibrant array of family entertainment including crafts, face painters, a magician, and puppet show. Walk on a circus tightrope with Esh Circus Arts, or climb and jump with the Knucklebones crew. Moms are invited to enjoy a free mini-massage thanks to local volunteer Massage Therapists. All families are welcome to decorate their wagons or strollers, bring a picnic, and enjoy springtime on the Common!
results.name: Duckling Day Parade

results.description:
Conditions won’t be perfect, but I think it’s worth a shot at a partial day sail to the harbor islands. There is a likelihood of showers part of the day and the wind will be off the ocean, so rain gear, gloves and warm layers are highly recommended. I also expect seas will be running high due to the persistent NE open fetch all week – if you are uncomfortable with boat pitching and rolling in swells, you may want to wait for a later trip.

The vessel is a cruising 34’ sailboat with a galley stove, teakettle, table, sink and head (toilet). There is a windscreen to make the cockpit a little more comfortable this time of year, and plenty of room down below to get out of the weather. Pans and utensils are aboard if anyone wants to heat up a lunch down below. We’ll eat at anchor tucked behind one of the islands.

Note: RSVP only if you will be there rain or shine. No shows that cost someone on a waitlist a seat will be not be considered for future trips.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet under the arch at the Boston Harbor Hotel
results.name: Enough with this weather sail

results.description:
So put on your walking shoes, already!  
Tours of the lilacs, live music, food and picnicking from dawn to dusk with refreshments and activities from 10am to 4pm. This is the oldest public arboretum in North America, and it showcases over 180 varieties of lilacs! The best time to see these blooms is on Lilac Sunday, held since 1908 to exhibit the pinnacle of lilac perfection. Take guided tours of the gardens, then sit back with a refreshment and enjoy acoustic music, storytelling, and traditional English dancing. 

PLEASE MEETUP AS A GROUP FIRST so we can stick together. 

We'll sign up at 11:00 for the 11:30 tour leaving from the Hunnewell Lawn , leading to the Lilac Collection.

When you get to the Lilac Collection, we'll try & sign up for the 12:30 Lilac Collection tour leaving shortly thereafter.

For more details check the 2016 schedule--
http://arboretum.harvard.edu/news-events/lilac-sunday/  
  
Parking:
Street parking along the Arboretum perimeter is limited and visitors are advised to take public transportation--
http://arboretum.harvard.edu/visit/directions/
[Quinn E. says: I say this every year, but in case you didn't hear- DO NOT DRIVE TO THE ARBORETUM ON LILAC SUNDAY! Take the Orange Line (it's a short walk from Forest Hills) or the 39 bus. Trust me.]
results.how_to_find_us: Meet near the main gate (Arborway Gate), in front of the park office shop (Hunnewell center). It'll be crowded so Duncan (host) will be wearing a distinctive black kangaroo hat.
results.name: Meet the Lilacs at Arnold Arboretum

results.description:
We will be joining 'Richard" and his group for this fun event ( The Boston Gay Single men's group) 

Join us for a leisurely walk through a section of Arnold Arboretum to view the extensive Lilac collection (hopefuly at peak bloom). Lilac Sunday is a perfect time to enjoy the Arboretum. We will meet at the Main Gate around 11:00AM.

It should be a very enjoyable outing.

About Lilac Sunday at Arnold Arboretum:

Of the thousands of flowering plants in the Arboretum, only one, the lilac, is singled out each year for a daylong celebration. Mainly located on the edge of Bussey Hill Road in the heart of the landscape, the lilac collection at the Arnold Arboretum is among the premier collections of these plants in North America.

Tours of the lilacs and other special collections, family activities, and food vendors make for a memorable day. Be a part of this beloved Boston tradition! Check back for the day-of schedule of events.

The Arboretum is open as usual from dawn to dusk. Activities are available from 10:00am to 3:00pm, and refreshments are available from 11:00am to 3:00pm.

Directons etc can be found at:

http://www.arboretum.harvard.edu/visit/directions/

results.description:
Enjoy the 108th "Lilac Sunday" at the Arnold Arboretum. It is FREE!  (Please Note: this is a cross-posting).


Of the thousands of flowering plants in the Arboretum, only one, the lilac, is singled out each year for a daylong celebration. With more than 370 lilac plants of 176 kinds, the Arboretum holds one of the premier lilac collections in North America.

Tours of the lilacs, family activities, food vendors, and picnicking (on this special day only) make for a memorable day. Be a part of this beloved Boston tradition!

On Lilac Sunday, the Arboretum is open as usual from dawn to dusk. Activities are scheduled from 10:00am to 3:00pm.


Bonus: also enjoy the Arboretum's Bonsai collection 

We will meet in front of the Hunnewell Visitor Center Building at the Main Gate. The plan is to join a Lilac Tour together. 

PLEASE NOTE: If you plan to picnic at the Arboretum, it is STRONGLY suggested to bring your own food/drink as the Food Trucks typically run out of food early in the day. (Guests are known to discreetly bring in a bottle of wine to enjoy with their picnic). 

For more info see http://www.Arboretum.Harvard.edu 

MBTA: Orange Line: Forest Hills stop. Street parking along the Arboretum perimeter is limited and visitors are STRONGLY advised to take public transportation

Enjoy the 108th "Lilac Sunday" at the Arnold Arboretum. It is FREE! 


Of the thousands of flowering plants in the Arboretum, only one, the lilac, is singled out each year for a daylong celebration. With more than 370 lilac plants of 176 kinds, the Arboretum holds one of the premier lilac collections in North America.

Tours of the lilacs, family activities, food vendors, and picnicking (on this special day only) make for a memorable day. Be a part of this beloved Boston tradition!

On Lilac Sunday, the Arboretum is open as usual from dawn to dusk. Activities are scheduled from 10:00am to 3:00pm.


Bonus: also enjoy the Arboretum's Bonsai collection 

We will meet in front of the Hunnewell Visitor Center Building at the Main Gate. The plan is to join a Lilac Tour together. 

PLEASE NOTE: If you plan to picnic at the Arboretum, it is STRONGLY suggested to bring your own food/drink as the Food Trucks typically run out of food early in the day. (Guests are known to discreetly bring in a bottle of wine to enjoy with their picnic). 

For more info see http://www.Arboretum.Harvard.edu 

MBTA: Orange Line: Forest Hills stop. Street parking along the Arboretum perimeter is limited and visitors are STRONGLY advised to take public transportation
results.name: "Lilac Sunday" at the Arboretum! FUN+Tours+Events+Food+FREE!

results.description:
From event host, Chris:

I've reserved a 30 minute block of the vertical wind tunnel at SkyVenture in Nashua, NH on Sunday May 8th! Space is limited - our session has room for up to 12 people (though I'm reserving 4 slots for myself and 3 others). Each participant would need to chip in $41.


The session starts at 1330EST (1:30pm). It's about an hour of preparation plus 30 minutes in their wind tunnel. Wear comfortable clothing and shoes with laces - preferably sneakers. They must not be loose shoes, and don't wear loose jewelry, or they will fall off and become a hazard! Maximum weight is 250lbs. If you have ever had a shoulder separation or shoulder surgery, you will NOT be allowed to participate (for safety sake).


If you don't want to go for the indoor skydiving, note that SkyVenture also has an awesome indoor surfing park, so if you want to learn surfing, you can also give that a shot while the others are in the wind tunnel.


We'll meet starting at 1200 (noon) at the plaza in front of 1 International Place, Boston, MA. We depart at 1230. I will be driving and can take 4 other people; I'll figure out more rides in the coming week.
results.name: Indoor Skydiving in NH !  limited space - cost $41

results.description:
Please be aware that this brunch takes place on Mother's Day! 

===============================================


Brunch Menu                                              Brunch for Thought FAQs

===============================================

                                         $$$ About Money $$$

Managing restaurant events is so much easier when everyone brings cash, so planning ahead is always a great idea:

(1) PLEASE BRING CASH to pay for your meal.

(2) Because we're dining as a group, everyone's orders will be listed on one bill. You will only pay for what you order; however, tax on food in MA is 6.25% and the minimum tip expected for a group at Boston-area restaurants is 18%. Please be prepared to add 25% to your order total in order to cover YOUR share of BOTH tax and tip.

(3) !!! PLEASE DON'T FORGET TO BRING CASH !!! It's the fastest and easiest way to settle up the bill.

==============================================


Hope to see you at The Painted Burro! ... anor ... ;-)
results.how_to_find_us: Ask for Anor's table (confirmed)
results.name: Brunch for Thought-May

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup with snacks and socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white t-shirt and a colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, pinnies, sunscreen, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be on the turf fields behind the playhouse. Look for people with light up discs!

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: As of 04/03/2016, our weekend MJ sessions have moved to Danvers -- we are no longer meeting in Saugus. The Danvers location is only about 7 minutes from Saugus and right off Rt 128 so hopefully Sunday attendees can still make it.


Please RSVP for this event so we can be sure to grab enough tables and bring enough Mah Jongg sets! 


Newcomers to American style Mah Jongg are welcome, provided that you have already learned the basics, as described on our About page! Thanks!

Note that MJ is usually played with 4 people, although it can be played with 2 or 3 as well, with some adjustment to the rules. If the number of RSVPs is not a multiple of 4, then we can decide whether to have multiple tables or have some sit out of some games and observe OR play a rack with another person. (This is a great way to learn!)

Preceding our regularly scheduled talk on Sunday May 8, the Humanist Hub is launching a new music-only program this Mother’s Day led by our new music director Antje Duvekot.
Award-winning Singer-Songwriter Antje Duvekot will be performing originals and selected covers on topics related to humanism, as well as lead the community in a number of sing-a-longs.
Singers and listeners alike are welcome to drop in half an hour before Greg Epstein’s Mother’s Day talk for some musical enjoyment/ camaraderie/ warm-up/ entertainment!
results.name: Community Music Program

results.description:
Let's do some spring flower photography. Challenge of the day: best bee closeup. Added challenge: try to take photos without people in them. :)


Join us for the 108th Annual Lilac Sunday celebration at the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University on Mothers’ Day, Sunday, May 8th. The event is centered around the Arboretum's premier collection of lilacs, located on the edge of Bussey Hill Road in the heart of the landscape. Hosted by the Arnold Arboretum and Food Truck Festivals of America, this celebration of springtime will include tours of the lilacs and other special collections, family activities, and food truck vendors.

Lilac Sunday is free and open to the public. Activities will take place from 10AM - 3PM, and the Arboretum is open as usual from dawn to dusk. Food trucks will be serving from 11AM - 3PM, offering everything from savory tacos to fall-off-the-bone BBQ to vegetarian treats to French Macaroons, and much more!


Tours and event activities will take place throughout the northern portion of the Arboretum, within short walking distance of the Arborway, Forest Hills, Centre Street, and South Street. For one day only for this special event, picnicking in the Arboretum is allowed.

Bring your camera and a variety of lenses, long zooms to take candids and bypass the people, wider angle lenses for sweeping views and macro lenses for flower closeups. A tripod is not recommended given the number of people. Dress according to weather, watch the comments for weather updates.


For more information, visit:

www.arboretum.harvard.edu/news-events/lilac-sunday

www.foodtruckfestivalsofamerica.com
results.name: Lilac Sunday at Arnold Arboretum

results.description:
***NOTE: This program is ideal for first time visitors to the Humanist Hub! We're excited to meet you. ***

If happy meals are for kids, do grown ups eat sad meals? Or, how can mature, responsible adults, in a world where adulting is hard, also sustain some of our youthful joy?

Join Humanist Chaplain and Hub Executive Director Greg Epstein, author of the New York Times bestselling book Good Without God, for his monthly talk at the Hub: this time featuring a conversation with his mother Judy Capel: child refugee from Cuba, hippie, retired executive, and supportive parent when her son took on one of the more unusual careers you can imagine. They’ll examine topics such as:

How children and parents learn to enjoy having honest, reality-based conversations with one another about the most important and challenging topics;

How can parents maintain their own sense of childlike joy, remembering you need to “put on your own oxygen mask before assisting others”, even while assuming all the adult responsibilities parenthood entails?

And perhaps most importantly, how might adult children and their adult parents transition into friendship while being honest--with a sense of humor-- about their own failures and humanity?

As usual: with music, food, poetry, discussion circles, and more.

SPECIAL OPPORTUNITY: arrive half an hour earlier for our the Humanist Hub’s first-ever monthly Community Music Program, with our award-winning new music director, Antje Duvekot. If you like good music, this is for you, and if you ever thought the best part of religion is the music, but you’re not religious, this is definitely for you.
results.name: Greg Epstein: On Being a Kid

group.name: The Humanist Hub in Harvard Square

results.description:
Have you ever tried to make a real change in your life, gotten stuck, frustrated, fed-up and finally gave up? And then realized you still want to make the change but don't know how to succeed? 

You are not alone!  This is a common theme for most people.  And this is because we aren't taught how change works and what we need to do to engage it.  

In this class, we'll discuss the elements of change and what to expect of them.  Just knowing what to expect can help to reduce your fear dramatically.  After all, it isn't the change we fear, it's whether or not we can HANDLE the change that scares us.  So when you know what to expect, it's easier to believe you can manage it.

You'll Learn:

• What the stages of change are (what to expect when you engage change) 

• What can get in the way of that change 

• How to help yourself get through it with as much grace and ease as possible 

Come and get a jump start on changing your life to be EXACTLY what you want it to be!  

PLEASE ARRIVE 10-15 minutes EARLY - We will be setting intentional space at 2:00PM and the doors will close to new arrivals at that time.  

Don't Wait To Register - Our classes tend to sell out well in advance of the class time.  We only have room for 15 people, so the space goes quickly.  Register now to save your space.

Parking is easily available on the street and because it's Sunday, you can park in the resident spaces without a permit. 


PLEASE do not wear fragrances!  Kelle is allergic to most fragrances (yes, even essential oils), so please do not wear them.
results.how_to_find_us: Same building as #19
results.name: Making REAL Change - SOLD OUT!

Intermediate level : Players with a good understanding of volleyball strategy and a good grasp of volleyball skills. Games require consistent bump, set, spike rallies. Therefore players should have good passing, setting and hitting skills. To ensure a quality level of play, preference will be given to players that are familiar with 5-1 or 6-2.  Please let me know which position(s) your prefer in your RSVP email. If you are not sure about your level or have any questions about this meetup please email the event host.


INSTRUCTIONS: If you'd like to play, please do the following:

1. Send an email to Valerie using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=12551965<a href="http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=12551965"></a>

There is a strict cap to make sure everyone gets lots of playing time. Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email.

Please respect the RSVP system. If you are RSVPed "YES" and fail to show or are repeatedly late to the meetups you will not be added to future meetups.

The cost of the meetup will be $5. Please pay the organizer when you arrive before the meetup starts. The money goes to cover the cost of the court rental. The entrance to the gym is on Cambridge Street opposite Harvard Market. The nearest intersection to the entrance is Cambridge Street and Roberts Road. The nearest T stop is Harvard Square. The gym is about a ten minute walk from the T stop. Parking near the school on Sundays is generally easy to find, as meters and residential parking rules are generally not enforced on Sundays (parking signs should say "EX SUNDAY" or similar).

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

group.name: The Light Within - Yoga, Reiki, Meditation - Dorchester MA

results.description:
With the upcoming 3-day Santo Christo Festival -May, 13-15, at St. Anthony's Parish in East Cambridge, our planning committee for the Barbecue that weekend  is open for volunteer participants  who would like to cook/serve/pray & eat. This is not a festival stand of any sorts, but our own small gathering for a few hours on late Sunday afternoon (for the meal), which could also include the buying of the meat & marinade (both sold at the Festival the night before), marinating overnight, purchasing and preparing the vegetables, skewering them for the group, and cooking them for everybody in our group. 

It's lots of fun and there are all types of other activities at the festival including Portuguese Folk Dancing, and the famously Grilled Sardines imported from the Azores, that were caught early Thursday morning and delivered to Logan Airport first thing Friday, the day of the Festival! (See photograph at the top of the page for the Monastic Cooking Club).

The Santo Cristo dos Milagres (Feast) Celebration was famously celebrated by Boston's own Cardinal Sean O'Malley in Portugal just a few years back with some of the local Priests of the Portuguese Community. In Portugal it is the largest Festival in the world held in October. Locally it has been a favorite every May for many many years in East Cambridge at San Antonio Parish on Cardinal Medeiros Avenue.

BBQ Portuguese Open Pit style is the method, and we add the influences of European Monastic Cooking with Organic vegetables such as red and green bell peppers, mushrooms, onions, tomatoes, summer squash and zucchini. 

Evening Prayer tomorrow will start at 6 p.m. sharp, followed by dinner and the planning/discussion for the barbeque next weekend. Dinner should be over by 8, but if participants would like to stay later they may.


We need volunteers for next weekend --everything from shopping to serving!

CALL 781-C-FRIARS for more information, directions, etc. THIS IS A FREE EVENT.

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/
results.how_to_find_us: Enter at The Hawthorne Building, the large glass doors to the left of H&R Block.

results.description:
Meet other members for a brief happy hour mingle.  An icebreaker will be provided to held facilitate mingling. Then you'll be seated for your series of four minute "mini-dates." On your dating card that you receive at check-in, you'll select who you wish to see again. You can choose Dating or Friendship as your preferred connection.

We will collect everyone's dating cards at the end of the event and email you your mutual matches within 48 hours.

While this event is geared towards helping people meet potential romantic matches, you can also mingle with all the guests and find new friends as well.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
Join the Fresh Pond Walking Community for our regular Sunday walk around Fresh Pond.   

Let's join regular walkers from surrounding towns + members of five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

results.description:
The oldest, established, permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and environs.

Please join the Fresh Pond Community walkers + five other meetup groups for this delightful sunset walk. 

Let's join 20+ walkers and some other walking groups for:

Over 3 years of reliable walking

Please note that this walk does not start at the same place as the other Fresh Pond walk.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
